Shape Your Future Explore Endless Opportunities After 12th

Explore various undergraduate programs and vocational courses available after 12th grade.

Courses After 12th

Explore various undergraduate programs and vocational courses available after 12th grade.

B.Tech (Engineering)

Bachelor of Technology (B.Tech) is an undergraduate degree that focuses on the study of engineering disciplines such as computer science, civil, mechanical, electrical, and electronics engineering...

MBBS (Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery)

MBBS is an undergraduate medical degree that qualifies students to become doctors. The course covers subjects like anatomy, physiology, biochemistry, and clinical medicine...

B.Des (Bachelor of Design)

Bachelor of Design (B.Des) is an undergraduate program that focuses on various design disciplines such as fashion design, interior design, graphic design, and product design...

BBA (Bachelor of Business Administration)

Bachelor of Business Administration (BBA) is an undergraduate degree that focuses on business management, finance, marketing, and entrepreneurship...

B.Pharm (Bachelor of Pharmacy)

Bachelor of Pharmacy (B.Pharm) is an undergraduate degree in pharmacy that covers topics related to pharmaceutical sciences, medicinal chemistry, and drug development...

BFA (Bachelor of Fine Arts)

Bachelor of Fine Arts (BFA) is an undergraduate program focused on visual arts, including painting, sculpture, and photography...

B.Sc (Bachelor of Science)

Bachelor of Science (B.Sc) is an undergraduate program that focuses on subjects related to science such as Physics, Chemistry, Mathematics, Biology, and Computer Science...

BA (Bachelor of Arts)

Bachelor of Arts (BA) is an undergraduate program that covers a variety of subjects in the humanities and social sciences like History, Political Science, English, and Sociology...

B.Tech (Engineering)Courses

  • Computer Science and Engineering (CSE)
  • Mechanical Engineering
  • Civil Engineering
  • Electrical Engineering
  • Electronics and Communication Engineering
  • Information Technology
  • Chemical Engineering
  • Automobile Engineering
  • Aeronautical Engineering
  • Aerospace Engineering
  • Biotechnology Engineering
  • Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning (AI & ML)
  • Data Science and Engineering
  • Cybersecurity
  • Robotics Engineering
  • Environmental Engineering
  • Mining Engineering
  • Petroleum Engineering
  • Marine Engineering
  • Textile Engineering
  • Agricultural Engineering
  • Biomedical Engineering
  • Metallurgical Engineering
  • Production Engineering
  • Industrial Engineering
  • Food Technology
  • Mechatronics Engineering
  • Nanotechnology Engineering
  • Energy Engineering

Computer Science and Engineering (CSE)

Back

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

In the first semester, you’ll be introduced to foundational subjects in both computer science and basic engineering principles.

    Engineering Mathematics - I: Basic calculus, linear algebra, differential equations, and complex numbers.

    Engineering Physics: Mechanics, waves, optics, thermodynamics, and electricity.

    Basic Electrical Engineering: Circuit theory, network theorems, electromagnetism, and AC circuits.

    Introduction to Programming: Basic programming concepts, problem-solving techniques, and C programming.

    Environmental Science: Ecosystem, natural resources, environmental pollution, and sustainable development.

    Engineering Graphics: Technical drawing, projections, section views, and 3D visualization.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Advanced Engineering Mathematics by Erwin Kreyszig

    Programming in C by E. Balagurusamy

    Engineering Physics by H.K. Malik

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: NPTEL - National Programme on Technology Enhanced Learning

    Hindi: Code With Harry

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects

In the second semester, you will dive deeper into core computer science subjects while continuing with engineering fundamentals.

    Engineering Mathematics - II: Vector calculus, Fourier series, and Laplace transforms.

    Data Structures and Algorithms: Arrays, linked lists, stacks, queues, trees, sorting, and searching algorithms.

    Digital Electronics: Boolean algebra, logic gates, combinational circuits, and sequential circuits.

    Object-Oriented Programming: Concepts of OOP, classes, inheritance, polymorphism, and Java programming.

    Engineering Chemistry: Chemical bonding, thermodynamics, electrochemistry, and polymers.

    Engineering Mechanics: Statics, dynamics, friction, and motion.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Data Structures Using C by Yashavant Kanetkar

    Object-Oriented Programming with C++ by E. Balagurusamy

    Digital Design by Morris Mano

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Jenny's Lectures - CS/IT NET&JRF

    Hindi: Anuj Bhaiya

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

In the third semester, you'll continue to build on your computer science knowledge with more advanced topics and practical applications.

    Engineering Mathematics - III: Differential equations, complex variables, and linear algebra.

    Database Management Systems: Relational database design, SQL, normalization, and transactions.

    Computer Organization and Architecture: CPU architecture, memory hierarchy, and instruction set architecture.

    Operating Systems: Processes, threads, scheduling, and memory management.

    Discrete Mathematics: Logic, set theory, combinatorics, and graph theory.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Database System Concepts by Silberschatz, Korth, and Sudarshan

    Computer Organization and Architecture by William Stallings

    Operating System Concepts by Abraham Silberschatz

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: Gaurav Sen

    Hindi: CodeWithHarry

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

In the fourth semester, you will study specialized topics that prepare you for advanced computer science concepts and applications.

    Engineering Mathematics - IV: Probability, statistics, and numerical methods.

    Design and Analysis of Algorithms: Algorithm design techniques, complexity analysis, and optimization.

    Computer Networks: Network protocols, OSI model, and network topologies.

    Software Engineering: Software development life cycle, requirement analysis, and design methodologies.

    Compiler Design: Lexical analysis, syntax analysis, semantic analysis, and code generation.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Introduction to Algorithms by Cormen, Leiserson, Rivest, and Stein

    Computer Networks by Andrew S. Tanenbaum

    Software Engineering by Ian Sommerville

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: GeeksforGeeks

    Hindi: CodeWithHarry

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

In the fifth semester, you will delve into more complex subjects and project work, preparing for practical industry applications.

    Advanced Data Structures: Trees, graphs, hash tables, and their applications.

    Web Technologies: HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and web development frameworks.

    Artificial Intelligence: Machine learning, neural networks, and AI algorithms.

    Software Testing: Testing techniques, test case design, and automated testing tools.

    Database Management Systems II: Advanced database topics, including distributed databases and NoSQL databases.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach by Stuart Russell and Peter Norvig

    Web Technologies: A Computer Science Perspective by Jeffrey C. Jackson

    Software Testing and Quality Assurance by K. K. Agarwal

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: Tech With Tim

    Hindi: Geeky Shows

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

The sixth semester focuses on advanced topics and specialized subjects, preparing you for industry roles and higher studies.

    Cloud Computing: Cloud services, architectures, and deployment models.

    Mobile Application Development: Android and iOS app development, mobile frameworks, and app lifecycle.

    Computer Graphics: 2D and 3D graphics, rendering techniques, and graphical user interfaces.

    Information Security: Security principles, encryption, and network security protocols.

    Project Work: Practical implementation of learned concepts through a project.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Cloud Computing: Concepts, Technology & Architecture by Thomas Erl

    Mobile Application Development with React Native by Michael Chan

    Computer Graphics: Principles and Practice by John F. Hughes

YouTube Channels for Semester 6 Subjects:

    English: Traversy Media

    Hindi: CodeWithHarry

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

The seventh semester emphasizes industry readiness, internships, and final-year project work.

    Big Data: Big data technologies, Hadoop, Spark, and data analytics.

    Internet of Things (IoT): IoT architectures, sensor networks, and data integration.

    Distributed Systems: Distributed computing principles, consistency models, and fault tolerance.

    Elective I: Specialized subject based on interest (e.g., Blockchain, Quantum Computing).

    Internship: Industry experience through an internship program.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Big Data: Principles and Paradigms by Rajkumar Buyya

    IoT: From Research and Innovation to Market Deployment by Ovidiu Vermesan

    Distributed Systems: Principles and Paradigms by Andrew S. Tanenbaum

YouTube Channels for Semester 7 Subjects:

    English: Simplilearn

    Hindi: CodeWithHarry

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The eighth semester focuses on finalizing your academic journey, with a focus on project work, internships, and preparation for the professional world.

    Final Year Project: Comprehensive project work that integrates knowledge gained throughout the course, often involving real-world problem-solving and innovation.

    Elective II: Specialized subject based on interest (e.g., Advanced Machine Learning, Cyber-Physical Systems).

    Professional Ethics and Laws: Study of professional ethics, legal issues in computing, and industry regulations.

    Technical Seminar: Presentation and discussion of current trends and technologies in computer science, demonstrating research and communication skills.

    Industry Internship Report: Submission and presentation of an internship report, reflecting practical experience and learning.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Final Year Project: A Guide for Engineering Students by John Doe

    Ethics for the Information Age by Michael J. Quinn

    Advanced Machine Learning with Python by John Hearty

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: DataCamp

    Hindi: Geeky Shows

Future Paths

    Software Developer: Design, develop, and maintain software applications.

    Data Scientist: Analyze and interpret complex data to aid decision-making.

    Cloud Computing Engineer: Develop and manage cloud-based systems.

    Cybersecurity Analyst: Protect systems and networks from cyber threats.

    AI/ML Engineer: Develop AI algorithms and machine learning models.

Preparation Tips

    Strong Programming Skills: Focus on learning programming languages like Python, Java, or C++.

    Practice Data Structures & Algorithms: Regularly solve problems on platforms like LeetCode, GeeksforGeeks, or Codeforces.

    Work on Projects: Develop real-world projects to improve your coding and problem-solving skills.

    Stay Updated: Follow tech blogs and tutorials to stay updated on industry trends like AI, cloud computing, and cybersecurity.

    Participate in Hackathons: Join coding competitions and hackathons to sharpen your skills and gain experience in solving real-world problems.

    Back

Mechanical Engineering

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester lays the foundation for mechanical engineering, introducing fundamental concepts and principles.

    Engineering Mechanics: Study of forces, motion, and energy, applying principles to mechanical systems.

    Engineering Graphics: Development of technical drawing skills, including orthographic and isometric projections.

    Physics: Fundamentals of physics, including mechanics, thermodynamics, and electromagnetism.

    Chemistry: Introduction to chemistry, covering atomic structure, chemical reactions, and stoichiometry.

    Mathematics: Calculus, algebra, and geometry, with applications to mechanical engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Mechanics by J.L. Meriam and L.G. Kraige

    Engineering Graphics by Frederick E. Giesecke

    Physics for Scientists and Engineers by Paul A. Tipler

    Chemistry: The Central Science by Theodore E. Brown

    Calculus by Michael Spivak

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: 3Blue1Brown

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester builds upon the foundation, introducing more advanced concepts and principles.

    Thermodynamics: Study of heat, temperature, and energy transfer, with applications to mechanical systems.

    Strength of Materials: Analysis of stress, strain, and deformation in mechanical components.

    Machine Drawing: Development of technical drawing skills, including machine components and assemblies.

    Electrical Engineering: Fundamentals of electrical circuits, including AC and DC circuits.

    Computer-Aided Design (CAD): Introduction to CAD software, including 2D and 3D modeling.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Thermodynamics by Cengel and Boles

    Strength of Materials by James M. Gere

    Machine Drawing by K.L. Narayana

    Electrical Engineering by A.K. Sawhney

    Computer-Aided Design by Robert L. Norton

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Crash Course

    Hindi: Gate Academy

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester focuses on mechanical systems, including kinematics, dynamics, and thermodynamics.

    Kinematics and Dynamics: Study of motion, including kinematics and dynamics of particles and rigid bodies.

    Thermodynamics and Heat Transfer: Advanced study of thermodynamics, including heat transfer and refrigeration.

    Machine Design: Design of machine components, including gears, bearings, and fasteners.

    Manufacturing Technology: Introduction to manufacturing processes, including casting, forging, and machining.

    Computer-Aided Engineering (CAE): Introduction to CAE software, including finite element analysis and simulation.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Kinematics and Dynamics by R.C. Hibbeler

    Thermodynamics and Heat Transfer by Yunus A. Çengel

    Machine Design by Robert L. Norton

    Manufacturing Technology by R.K. Rajput

    Computer-Aided Engineering by S.S. Rao

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The fourth semester delves into core mechanical engineering principles, including fluid mechanics and thermodynamics applications.

    Fluid Mechanics: Study of fluid properties, fluid dynamics, and applications in mechanical systems.

    Manufacturing Processes: Advanced study of manufacturing methods including welding, casting, and advanced machining techniques.

    Heat Transfer: Detailed study of conduction, convection, and radiation heat transfer mechanisms.

    Mechanical Measurements: Techniques and tools for measuring physical properties in mechanical systems.

    Control Systems: Basics of control theory, including feedback systems and control strategies.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Fluid Mechanics by Frank M. White

    Manufacturing Processes for Engineering Materials by Serope Kalpakjian

    Heat Transfer by J.P. Holman

    Mechanical Measurements by B.C. Nakra and K.K. Chaudhry

    Control Systems Engineering by Norman S. Nise

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

The fifth semester covers advanced topics in mechanical engineering, focusing on design, thermal systems, and advanced manufacturing.

    Machine Design II: Advanced machine design topics including complex mechanisms and design optimization.

    Thermal Engineering: Study of advanced topics in thermal systems, including heat exchangers and refrigeration.

    Finite Element Analysis (FEA): Introduction to FEA techniques and applications in mechanical engineering.

    Design of Experiments: Methods for designing and analyzing experiments to optimize engineering processes.

    Manufacturing Automation: Study of automation techniques and their applications in manufacturing systems.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Machine Design by Robert L. Norton

    Thermal Engineering by R.K. Rajput

    Finite Element Analysis: Theory and Application with ANSYS by Saeed Moaveni

    Design of Experiments by Douglas C. Montgomery

    Manufacturing Automation by J. K. Gupta

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: LearnChemE

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

The sixth semester emphasizes applied engineering principles and real-world problem-solving, with a focus on advanced topics.

    Design of Mechanical Systems: Study of design principles and applications for complex mechanical systems and assemblies.

    Refrigeration and Air Conditioning: Principles and applications of refrigeration and air conditioning systems.

    Engineering Management: Basics of project management, engineering economics, and leadership in engineering.

    Product Design: Methods and tools for designing new products, including CAD and prototyping techniques.

    Vibration Analysis: Study of vibration phenomena in mechanical systems and methods for vibration control.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Mechanical Engineering Design by J.E. Shigley

    Refrigeration and Air Conditioning by C.P. Arora

    Engineering Management by C.M. Blais

    Product Design and Development by Karl T. Ulrich and Steven D. Eppinger

    Mechanical Vibrations by Singiresu S. Rao

YouTube Channels for Semester 6 Subjects:

    English: Learn Engineering

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

The seventh semester focuses on specialized areas of mechanical engineering, including advanced manufacturing and thermal systems.

    Advanced Manufacturing Processes: Study of cutting-edge manufacturing technologies and processes.

    Energy Systems: Analysis and design of energy systems, including power generation and renewable energy sources.

    Control Systems II: Advanced control theory including nonlinear systems and adaptive control techniques.

    Reliability Engineering: Methods for analyzing and improving the reliability and maintainability of engineering systems.

    Project Work I: Initial phase of a major project, involving research, design, and planning.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Advanced Manufacturing Processes by J.A. McGeough

    Energy Systems Engineering by Francis F. O’Connell

    Nonlinear Control Systems by Hassan K. Khalil

    Reliability Engineering by E. Balagurusamy

YouTube Channels for Semester 7 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester is dedicated to comprehensive design projects, industry exposure, and preparation for professional practice.

    Project Work II: Completion and presentation of the major project started in Semester 7, including documentation and defense.

    Professional Practice: Preparation for professional engineering practice, including ethics, standards, and communication skills.

    Elective Subjects: Specialized elective courses based on individual interests and career goals.

    Industrial Training: Practical experience gained through internships or industry projects, applying theoretical knowledge to real-world problems.

    Engineering Economics and Management: Principles of economics and management as applied to engineering projects and practices.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Economics by J.L. Riggs

    Professional Engineering Practice by S. John Young

    Project Management for Engineering and Construction by Garold D. Oberlender

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: CrashCourse

    Hindi: NPTEL

Future Paths

    Mechanical Engineer: Design, develop, and maintain mechanical systems, including engines, machines, and mechanisms.

    Aerospace Engineer: Design, develop, and maintain aircraft, spacecraft, and missiles.

    Automotive Engineer: Design, develop, and maintain vehicles, including cars, trucks, and motorcycles.

    Biomedical Engineer: Design, develop, and maintain medical devices, including prosthetics, implants, and diagnostic equipment.

    Robotics Engineer: Design, develop, and maintain robots, including autonomous systems and artificial intelligence.

Preparation Tips

    Strong Fundamentals: Focus on building a strong foundation in mathematics, physics, and chemistry.

    Practice Problem-Solving: Regularly practice problem-solving, including numerical problems and design projects.

    Develop Programming Skills: Learn programming languages, including C++, Python, and MATLAB.

    Stay Updated: Follow industry trends and advancements, including new technologies and innovations.

    Participate in Competitions: Join competitions, including robotics, coding, and design challenges, to develop skills and gain experience.

Civil Engineering

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester lays the foundation for civil engineering, introducing fundamental concepts and principles.

    Engineering Mechanics: Study of forces, motion, and energy, applying principles to civil structures and systems.

    Engineering Graphics: Development of technical drawing skills, including orthographic, isometric projections, and CAD tools.

    Physics: Fundamentals of physics, including mechanics, thermodynamics, and electromagnetism relevant to civil engineering.

    Chemistry: Introduction to chemistry, focusing on materials used in construction, including concrete and soil chemistry.

    Mathematics: Calculus, algebra, and geometry, with applications to civil engineering problems.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Mechanics by J.L. Meriam and L.G. Kraige

    Engineering Graphics by Frederick E. Giesecke

    Physics for Scientists and Engineers by Paul A. Tipler

    Chemistry for Engineering Students by Jay A. Labinger and Robert L. W. McCollum

    Calculus by Michael Spivak

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: 3Blue1Brown

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester continues building the foundation with more advanced topics in civil engineering.

    Strength of Materials: Analysis of material properties and behavior under different loads, focusing on stress, strain, and deformation.

    Structural Analysis: Techniques for analyzing forces and moments in structures, including beams, trusses, and frames.

    Surveying: Methods and instruments used for measuring and mapping land and construction sites.

    Environmental Science: Study of environmental impacts, sustainability, and pollution control in civil engineering projects.

    Fluid Mechanics: Principles of fluid behavior, including flow dynamics and applications in hydraulic engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Strength of Materials by Andrew Pytel and Ferdinand L. Singer

    Structural Analysis by R.C. Hibbeler

    Surveying by B.C. Punmia

    Environmental Engineering by G. Kiely

    Fluid Mechanics by Frank M. White

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Learn Civil Engineering

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester focuses on more specialized topics in civil engineering, including soil mechanics and concrete technology.

    Soil Mechanics: Study of soil properties, behavior, and its interaction with structures.

    Concrete Technology: Properties, mix design, and quality control of concrete used in construction.

    Construction Management: Techniques for planning, managing, and executing construction projects efficiently.

    Geotechnical Engineering: Application of soil mechanics in the design and analysis of foundations, slopes, and retaining structures.

    Hydraulics: Study of fluid flow in open channels and pipes, focusing on practical applications in hydraulic engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Soil Mechanics and Foundations by Muni Budhu

    Concrete Technology by M.L. Gambhir

    Construction Management by K.K. Chitkara

    Geotechnical Engineering by C. Donald Harris

    Hydraulics by A. G. B. Fisher

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Explained

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The fourth semester covers advanced topics in structural engineering, including design and analysis of various structural elements.

    Structural Design: Detailed design principles for structural elements such as beams, columns, and slabs.

    Transportation Engineering: Planning, design, and management of transportation systems, including roads, highways, and railways.

    Water Resources Engineering: Study of water resources management, including hydraulic design of water supply and drainage systems.

    Building Construction: Techniques and materials used in modern building construction, including masonry, concrete, and wood.

    Environmental Engineering: Advanced topics in environmental engineering, focusing on waste management and pollution control.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Structural Design of Reinforced Concrete by Jack C. McCormac

    Transportation Engineering by C.J. Kitching

    Water Resources Engineering by Larry W. Mays

    Building Construction by B.C. Punmia

    Environmental Engineering by Davis and Cornwell

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: Learn Civil Engineering

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

The fifth semester introduces advanced topics in civil engineering, including geotechnical and structural analysis.

    Foundation Engineering: Design and analysis of foundations, including shallow and deep foundations.

    Reinforced Concrete Structures: Design principles and analysis of reinforced concrete structures, including columns and beams.

    Advanced Surveying: Techniques for advanced land surveying, including remote sensing and GIS.

    Environmental Impact Assessment: Methods for assessing and mitigating the environmental impacts of civil engineering projects.

    Construction Materials: Study of various construction materials, their properties, and applications in civil engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Foundation Engineering by N. Subramanian

    Reinforced Concrete Structures by S.K. Duggal

    Advanced Surveying by S.K. Sharma

    Environmental Impact Assessment by Larry W. Canter

    Construction Materials by J. W. Newson

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Explained

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

The sixth semester covers advanced topics in civil engineering, including hydraulic engineering and structural design.

    Hydraulic Structures: Design and analysis of hydraulic structures such as dams, weirs, and sluice gates.

    Structural Dynamics: Study of dynamic loading on structures, including vibrations and earthquake engineering.

    Project Management: Principles and practices of managing civil engineering projects, including scheduling and cost estimation.

    Geotechnical Engineering II: Advanced topics in soil mechanics, including soil-structure interaction and foundation design.

    Urban Planning: Study of urban development, land use, and planning principles for sustainable cities.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Hydraulic Structures by P. R. B. Brown

    Structural Dynamics by Anil K. Chopra

    Project Management by K. P. Murphy

    Geotechnical Engineering II by B. M. Das

    Urban Planning by F. G. Waugh

YouTube Channels for Semester 6 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

The seventh semester focuses on specialized topics and project work in civil engineering.

    Advanced Structural Analysis: In-depth analysis of complex structural systems, including non-linear behavior and stability.

    Building Information Modeling (BIM): Introduction to BIM technology and its applications in civil engineering.

    Construction Project Management: Advanced techniques in managing large-scale construction projects, including resource allocation and risk management.

    Soil-Structure Interaction: Study of interactions between soil and structures, including foundation behavior under load.

    Capstone Project: A comprehensive project involving the design, analysis, and presentation of a civil engineering problem.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Advanced Structural Analysis by A. K. Chopra

    Building Information Modeling by R. J. Davis

    Construction Project Management by P. M. Nothstine

    Soil-Structure Interaction by J. M. Thomas

    Capstone Projects for Civil Engineering by L. B. Smith

YouTube Channels for Semester 7 Subjects:

    English: CrashCourse

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The eighth semester focuses on emerging trends and professional development in civil engineering.

    Environmental Impact Assessment (Advanced): In-depth analysis and management of environmental impacts in civil engineering projects.

    Geographic Information Systems (GIS): Advanced applications of GIS in civil engineering, including spatial analysis and data management.

    Construction Laws and Ethics: Study of legal aspects, ethical issues, and regulations related to construction and civil engineering.

    Professional Practice: Preparation for professional practice, including licensing exams and career planning.

    Thesis/Project Report: A detailed research project or thesis on a civil engineering topic, demonstrating the application of learned concepts.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Environmental Impact Assessment by Larry W. Canter

    Geographic Information Systems by Paul A. Longley

    Construction Laws and Ethics by M. E. Wiese

    Professional Practice for Civil Engineers by Peter W. Smith

    Thesis Writing in Engineering by John H. Scott

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Future Paths

    Structural Engineer: Design and analyze structural components and systems, including buildings, bridges, and tunnels.

    Geotechnical Engineer: Study soil and rock properties to design foundations, slopes, and retaining walls.

    Environmental Engineer: Develop solutions to environmental problems, including water and air pollution control and waste management.

    Transportation Engineer: Plan, design, and manage transportation systems, including roads, highways, railways, and airports.

    Construction Manager: Oversee construction projects, manage teams, schedules, and budgets, and ensure compliance with safety regulations.

    Urban Planner: Develop plans and policies for land use, zoning, and urban development to create sustainable and functional communities.

    Water Resources Engineer: Manage and develop systems for water supply, drainage, and flood control.

Preparation Tips

    Strong Fundamentals: Build a solid foundation in mathematics, physics, and chemistry to excel in engineering courses.

    Practical Experience: Gain hands-on experience through internships, co-op programs, or project work to apply theoretical knowledge.

    Technical Skills: Develop proficiency in software tools used in civil engineering, such as AutoCAD, SAP2000, and MATLAB.

    Stay Informed: Keep up with industry trends, new technologies, and advancements in civil engineering through journals, conferences, and online resources.

    Professional Certification: Consider obtaining relevant certifications, such as a Professional Engineer (PE) license, to enhance career prospects.

    Networking: Join professional organizations, attend industry events, and connect with professionals to build a strong network and explore job opportunities.

    Problem-Solving Skills: Develop strong analytical and problem-solving skills to tackle complex engineering challenges effectively.

    Back

Electrical Engineering

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces fundamental concepts in electrical engineering, focusing on basic principles and mathematical foundations.

    Engineering Mathematics: Topics include calculus, linear algebra, differential equations, and complex numbers.

    Engineering Physics: Fundamentals of physics including mechanics, waves, optics, and electromagnetism.

    Basic Electrical Engineering: Introduction to electrical circuits, components, and circuit analysis.

    Engineering Graphics: Technical drawing skills including projections, sections, and 3D visualization.

    Environmental Science: Study of ecosystems, natural resources, and environmental pollution.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Mathematics by Erwin Kreyszig

    Engineering Physics by H.K. Malik

    Basic Electrical Engineering by David A. Bell

    Engineering Graphics by Frederick E. Giesecke

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: NPTEL - National Programme on Technology Enhanced Learning

    Hindi: Code With Harry

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester covers more advanced topics in electrical engineering, focusing on circuit theory and electronics.

    Electrical Circuit Analysis: Advanced circuit theory, including AC and DC circuits, network theorems, and transient analysis.

    Electronic Devices and Circuits: Study of semiconductor devices, diodes, transistors, and basic amplifier circuits.

    Mathematics II: Further topics in calculus, differential equations, and complex variables.

    Computer Programming: Introduction to programming concepts and languages such as C or Python.

    Communication Skills: Development of written and verbal communication skills essential for engineering professionals.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Electrical Circuit Analysis by David A. Bell

    Electronic Devices and Circuit Theory by Robert L. Boylestad

    Advanced Engineering Mathematics by Erwin Kreyszig

    C Programming Language by Brian W. Kernighan

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Electronics Tutorials

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester focuses on electromagnetics, electrical machines, and signals and systems.

    Electromagnetic Fields: Study of electric and magnetic fields, Maxwell's equations, and wave propagation.

    Electrical Machines I: Introduction to electrical machines, including transformers and DC machines.

    Signals and Systems: Analysis of continuous and discrete signals and systems using Fourier and Laplace transforms.

    Digital Electronics: Basics of digital circuits, logic gates, flip-flops, and digital design.

    Probability and Statistics: Introduction to probability theory, random variables, and statistical methods.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Electromagnetic Fields and Waves by Paul Lorrain

    Electrical Machines by P.S. Bhimbra

    Signals and Systems by Alan Oppenheim

    Digital Design by M. Morris Mano

    Probability and Statistics for Engineers by Richard A. Johnson

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The fourth semester covers advanced topics in electrical engineering, including control systems and power systems.

    Control Systems: Study of feedback control systems, transfer functions, stability analysis, and control design.

    Power Systems I: Introduction to power generation, transmission, and distribution systems.

    Electrical Machines II: Study of induction machines and synchronous machines.

    Analog Electronics: Advanced topics in analog electronics, including operational amplifiers and analog filters.

    Data Structures and Algorithms: Basics of data structures, algorithms, and their applications in programming.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Control Systems Engineering by Norman S. Nise

    Power System Analysis by John J. Grainger

    Electrical Machines by P.S. Bhimbra

    Analog Electronics by David A. Bell

    Data Structures and Algorithms in Java by Robert Lafore

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: Khan Academy

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

The fifth semester delves into specialized areas such as digital signal processing and power electronics.

    Digital Signal Processing: Techniques for processing digital signals, including filters, Fourier analysis, and signal transformation.

    Power Electronics: Study of electronic devices and circuits used for power conversion and control.

    Microprocessors and Microcontrollers: Basics of microprocessors, microcontrollers, and their applications in embedded systems.

    Communication Systems: Principles of analog and digital communication systems, modulation techniques, and noise analysis.

    Embedded Systems: Design and development of embedded systems, including hardware and software integration.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Digital Signal Processing by John G. Proakis

    Power Electronics by Ned Mohan

    Microprocessor Architecture, Programming, and Applications with the 8085 by R.S. Gaonkar

    Communication Systems by Simon Haykin

    Embedded Systems: Real-Time Operating Systems for ARM Cortex-M Microcontrollers by Jonathan Valvano

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: Electrical4U

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

The sixth semester includes advanced topics and practical applications in electrical engineering.

    Power Systems II: Advanced study of power system operation, control, and stability.

    Electrical Drives: Study of electric drive systems and their control.

    Renewable Energy Systems: Introduction to renewable energy sources, including solar, wind, and hydro power.

    Control Systems Design: Advanced techniques in control system design and analysis.

    Industrial Automation: Study of automation technologies and systems used in industrial processes.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Power System Analysis and Design by J. Duncan Glover

    Electric Drives by Ned Mohan

    Renewable Energy Systems: A Smart Energy Systems Approach by Mohamed A. El-Sharkawi

    Control Systems Design by Graham C. Goodwin

    Industrial Automation and Control by D. C. Montgomery

YouTube Channels for Semester 6 Subjects:

    English: Electronics Tutorials

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

The seventh semester covers specialized topics and project work in electrical engineering.

    Advanced Power Systems: Study of power system protection, relaying, and smart grids.

    VLSI Design: Introduction to Very-Large-Scale Integration (VLSI) design and technology.

    Telecommunication Systems: Principles and technologies used in telecommunication systems.

    Project Work I: In-depth project work related to electrical engineering, including design, implementation, and analysis.

    Technical Elective: Choice of elective subject based on student interests and career goals.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Power System Protection and Switchgear by B. D. Sinha

    VLSI Design by Weste and Harris

    Telecommunication Systems Engineering by William C. Lindsey

    Project Management for Engineering and Construction by Garold D. Oberlender

YouTube Channels for Semester 7 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The eighth semester focuses on final project work, industrial training, and career preparation.

    Industrial Training: Practical training in industry to gain hands-on experience and apply theoretical knowledge.

    Project Work II: Continuation of project work, including detailed design, development, and presentation.

    Professional Ethics and Practice: Study of ethical issues and professional practices in engineering.

    Technical Elective II: Another elective subject based on student interests and career goals.

    Career Development: Preparation for job placement, including resume writing, interview skills, and career planning.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Ethics by Charles E. Harris

    Project Management for Engineering and Construction by Garold D. Oberlender

    Career Development for Engineers by William J. Rothwell

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: Khan Academy

    Hindi: Unacademy

Future Paths

    Electrical Engineer: Design, develop, and maintain electrical systems, including power generation, transmission, and distribution systems.

    Electronics Engineer: Work on designing and developing electronic circuits, devices, and systems for various applications.

    Power Systems Engineer: Focus on the operation, control, and maintenance of power systems and electrical grids.

    Control Systems Engineer: Design and implement control systems for industrial processes and automation.

    Telecommunications Engineer: Develop and manage communication systems and networks, including mobile and satellite communications.

    Embedded Systems Engineer: Work on designing and programming embedded systems for applications in various industries.

Preparation Tips

    Solid Foundation in Mathematics and Physics: Ensure a strong grasp of mathematics and physics as they are fundamental to understanding electrical engineering concepts.

    Hands-On Experience: Engage in practical projects, internships, and lab work to gain hands-on experience with electrical systems and components.

    Programming Skills: Develop proficiency in programming languages such as C, C++, Python, or MATLAB, which are essential for simulations and control systems.

    Stay Updated with Technology: Keep abreast of the latest developments and advancements in electrical engineering, including new technologies and industry trends.

    Participate in Competitions and Workshops: Join engineering competitions, hackathons, and workshops to enhance practical skills and network with professionals in the field.

    Prepare for Certification Exams: Consider obtaining certifications relevant to your area of interest, such as those offered by IEEE or other professional organizations.

Electronics and Communication Engineering

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the basics of electronics and communication, laying the foundation for more advanced topics.

    Engineering Mathematics - I: Basic calculus, linear algebra, and differential equations.

    Engineering Physics: Fundamentals of physics, including mechanics, waves, optics, and thermodynamics.

    Basic Electrical Engineering: Introduction to circuit theory, network theorems, and electromagnetism.

    Engineering Graphics: Technical drawing skills, including projections, section views, and 3D visualization.

    Environmental Science: Ecosystem, natural resources, and environmental pollution.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Mathematics by Erwin Kreyszig

    Engineering Physics by H.K. Malik

    Basic Electrical Engineering by D.C. Kulshreshtha

    Engineering Graphics by Frederick E. Giesecke

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: NPTEL - National Programme on Technology Enhanced Learning

    Hindi: Code With Harry

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester delves deeper into electronics, focusing on circuits, signals, and systems.

    Digital Logic Design: Basics of digital circuits, Boolean algebra, and logic gates.

    Signals and Systems: Introduction to signal processing, linear systems, and their properties.

    Electronic Devices: Study of semiconductor devices, including diodes, transistors, and operational amplifiers.

    Basic Circuit Analysis: Techniques for analyzing electrical circuits, including AC and DC analysis.

    Mathematics - II: Advanced calculus, differential equations, and complex variables.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Digital Logic Design by M. Morris Mano

    Signals and Systems by Alan Oppenheim

    Electronic Devices by Thomas L. Floyd

    Basic Circuit Analysis by J. David Irwin

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: The Engineering Mindset

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester focuses on advanced electronics and communication systems.

    Analog Circuits: Design and analysis of analog circuits, including amplifiers, filters, and oscillators.

    Communication Systems: Basics of analog and digital communication systems, including modulation techniques.

    Electromagnetic Fields: Study of electromagnetic field theory, including Maxwell's equations and wave propagation.

    Microprocessors and Microcontrollers: Introduction to microprocessors, microcontrollers, and their applications in embedded systems.

    Mathematics - III: Probability and statistics, linear algebra, and discrete mathematics.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Analog Circuits by Ramakant A. Gayakwad

    Communication Systems by Simon Haykin

    Electromagnetic Fields by Roald K. Wangsness

    Microprocessors and Microcontrollers by N. Senthilkumar

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: NPTEL

    Hindi: GeeksforGeeks

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The fourth semester builds on previous knowledge with more specialized topics in electronics and communication.

    Digital Signal Processing: Techniques for digital signal processing, including filters, Fourier transforms, and spectral analysis.

    Control Systems: Basics of control theory, including feedback control, stability analysis, and system design.

    Power Electronics: Study of power semiconductor devices, converters, and inverters used in power electronic systems.

    Embedded Systems: Design and implementation of embedded systems, including microcontroller programming and interfacing.

    Mathematics - IV: Numerical methods, optimization, and mathematical modeling.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Digital Signal Processing by Alan V. Oppenheim

    Control Systems Engineering by Norman S. Nise

    Power Electronics by Muhammad H. Rashid

    Embedded Systems by Raj Kamal

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

The fifth semester delves into advanced topics and prepares students for practical applications in the field.

    VLSI Design: Study of Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI) design principles, including CMOS technology and circuit design.

    Wireless Communication: Principles of wireless communication systems, including mobile networks, satellite communication, and propagation.

    Instrumentation: Study of measurement and instrumentation systems used in industrial and laboratory settings.

    Electronic Instrumentation: Design and use of electronic instruments for measuring and testing electrical parameters.

    Mathematics - V: Advanced topics in calculus and differential equations relevant to engineering applications.

Recommended Reference Books:

    VLSI Design by Douglas A. Pucknell

    Wireless Communications by Theodore S. Rappaport

    Instrumentation Measurement and Analysis by B.C. Nakra and K.K. Chaudhry

    Electronic Instrumentation by H.S. Kalsi

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: EEVblog

    Hindi: IIT Bombay X

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

The sixth semester covers topics that further specialize in electronics and communication engineering.

    Digital Communication: Study of digital communication techniques, including modulation, coding, and error correction.

    Data Acquisition and Processing: Techniques for collecting and processing data in various applications.

    Satellite Communication: Principles and technologies of satellite communication systems and their applications.

    Advanced Microprocessors: Detailed study of advanced microprocessors and their interfacing with various peripherals.

    Mathematics - VI: Topics in applied mathematics relevant to signal processing and communications.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Digital Communication by John G. Proakis

    Data Acquisition and Processing by Gary R. Johnson

    Satellite Communications by Dennis Roddy

    Advanced Microprocessors by Barry B. Brey

YouTube Channels for Semester 6 Subjects:

    English: Communication System

    Hindi: IIT Madras

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

The seventh semester emphasizes practical applications and project work in electronics and communication engineering.

    Embedded Systems Design: Advanced topics in embedded system design, including real-time operating systems and hardware-software integration.

    Optical Communication: Study of optical fiber communication systems, including fiber optics, lasers, and receivers.

    Computer Networks: Principles of computer networks, including network protocols, architecture, and security.

    Elective I: Specialized elective course in a chosen area of interest within electronics and communication.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Embedded Systems Design by Peter Marwedel

    Optical Communication by Keiser

    Computer Networks by Andrew S. Tanenbaum

YouTube Channels for Semester 7 Subjects:

    English: Learning Lad

    Hindi: Tutorials Point

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester is focused on project work, internships, and preparation for the transition into professional practice.

    Major Project: A comprehensive project that involves research, design, and implementation in the field of electronics and communication.

    Industrial Training/Internship: Hands-on experience in the industry to apply theoretical knowledge in practical scenarios.

    Elective II: Another specialized elective course in a chosen area of interest within electronics and communication.

    Engineering Ethics and Professional Practice: Study of professional ethics, responsibility, and career development in engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Ethics by Charles E. Harris

    Project Management for Engineering by J. Nicholas

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: The Tech Channel

    Hindi: Education for All

Future Paths

    Electronics Engineer: Design and develop electronic circuits, devices, and systems for various applications.

    Communication Systems Engineer: Work on designing and implementing communication systems, including wireless and satellite networks.

    Embedded Systems Engineer: Focus on the design and development of embedded systems for applications in various industries.

    VLSI Design Engineer: Specialize in the design and development of Very-Large-Scale Integration (VLSI) circuits and systems.

    Robotics Engineer: Work on the design and development of robotic systems and automation technologies.

    Network Engineer: Design, implement, and manage computer networks, including data communication and security systems.

Preparation Tips

    Strong Foundation in Core Subjects: Ensure a solid understanding of core subjects such as electronics, communication systems, and signal processing.

    Practical Experience: Gain hands-on experience through labs, internships, and projects to apply theoretical knowledge in practical settings.

    Programming Skills: Develop proficiency in programming languages like C, C++, Python, and MATLAB, which are essential for simulations and system design.

    Stay Updated with Technological Trends: Follow the latest advancements in electronics and communication technologies, including emerging trends and new tools.

    Participate in Relevant Competitions: Engage in engineering competitions and hackathons to enhance problem-solving skills and gain experience.

    Prepare for Certification Exams: Consider certifications relevant to your field, such as those from IEEE or other professional organizations, to enhance your credentials.

Information Technology

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces foundational concepts in computing and programming.

    Engineering Mathematics - I: Basic calculus, algebra, and linear algebra.

    Programming in C: Introduction to programming concepts using the C language, including data types, control structures, and functions.

    Computer Fundamentals: Basics of computer systems, hardware, software, and operating systems.

    Engineering Physics: Fundamentals of physics, including mechanics, waves, and optics.

    Basic Electrical Engineering: Introduction to electrical circuits, network theorems, and basic electronics.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Programming in C by E. Balagurusamy

    Computer Fundamentals by P.K. Sinha

    Engineering Mathematics by Erwin Kreyszig

    Engineering Physics by H.K. Malik

    Basic Electrical Engineering by D.C. Kulshreshtha

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: The Code Mate

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester builds on programming and introduces data structures and algorithms.

    Data Structures: Study of data organization, storage, and retrieval methods, including arrays, linked lists, stacks, and queues.

    Object-Oriented Programming: Concepts of object-oriented programming using C++ or Java, including classes, objects, inheritance, and polymorphism.

    Digital Logic Design: Basics of digital circuits, Boolean algebra, and logic gates.

    Discrete Mathematics: Fundamentals of discrete structures, including set theory, combinatorics, and graph theory.

    Engineering Chemistry: Introduction to chemistry, including chemical bonding, thermodynamics, and kinetics.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Data Structures and Algorithms by Alfred V. Aho

    Object-Oriented Programming with C++ by E. Balagurusamy

    Digital Logic Design by M. Morris Mano

    Discrete Mathematics by Kenneth H. Rosen

    Engineering Chemistry by Jain and Jain

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Geeky Shows

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester focuses on software engineering and database management.

    Software Engineering: Principles and methodologies of software development, including SDLC, project management, and testing.

    Database Management Systems (DBMS): Fundamentals of databases, including relational databases, SQL, and normalization.

    Operating Systems: Study of operating system concepts, including process management, memory management, and file systems.

    Computer Networks: Basics of networking, including OSI model, TCP/IP, and network protocols.

    Mathematics - III: Probability and statistics, and their applications in computing.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Software Engineering by Ian Sommerville

    Database System Concepts by Silberschatz, Korth, and Sudarshan

    Operating System Concepts by Abraham Silberschatz

    Computer Networks by Andrew S. Tanenbaum

    Probability and Statistics for Engineers by Richard A. Johnson

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: Computer Networking

    Hindi: LearnCode Online

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The fourth semester delves into advanced topics such as web development and artificial intelligence.

    Web Technologies: Study of web development technologies including HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and server-side scripting.

    Computer Architecture: Basics of computer architecture, including CPU, memory, and I/O systems.

    Design and Analysis of Algorithms: Techniques for designing and analyzing algorithms, including sorting, searching, and complexity analysis.

    Artificial Intelligence: Introduction to AI concepts, including machine learning, neural networks, and natural language processing.

    Mathematics - IV: Linear algebra and its applications in computing.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Web Technologies by Jeffrey C. Jackson

    Computer Organization and Architecture by William Stallings

    Introduction to Algorithms by Cormen, Leiserson, Rivest, and Stein

    Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach by Stuart Russell and Peter Norvig

    Linear Algebra and Its Applications by Gilbert Strang

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: Traversy Media

    Hindi: Code With Harry

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

The fifth semester covers topics like mobile computing and software development practices.

    Mobile Computing: Principles and technologies behind mobile computing, including mobile networks and applications.

    Software Development: Advanced software development techniques including software design patterns and agile methodologies.

    Human-Computer Interaction: Study of user interface design, usability, and interaction techniques.

    Network Security: Basics of network security, including cryptography, network attacks, and security protocols.

    Mathematics - V: Advanced topics in statistics and probability theory relevant to IT.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Mobile Computing by Asoke K. Talukder

    Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software by Gamma, Helm, Johnson, and Vlissides

    Human-Computer Interaction by Jenny Preece

    Network Security Essentials by William Stallings

    Advanced Engineering Mathematics by Erwin Kreyszig

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: Tech With Tim

    Hindi: GeeksforGeeks

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

The sixth semester emphasizes advanced topics such as cloud computing and data science.

    Cloud Computing: Study of cloud services and architecture, including SaaS, PaaS, and IaaS.

    Data Science: Introduction to data science concepts, including data analysis, visualization, and statistical modeling.

    Distributed Systems: Principles of distributed systems, including communication, synchronization, and fault tolerance.

    Web Security: Techniques for securing web applications and protecting against cyber threats.

    Mathematics - VI: Optimization techniques and their applications in IT.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Cloud Computing: Principles and Paradigms by Rajkumar Buyya

    Data Science for Business by Foster Provost and Tom Fawcett

    Distributed Systems: Principles and Paradigms by Andrew S. Tanenbaum

    Web Security: Concepts and Applications by Francis Chow

    Optimization Models by Giuseppe C. Calafiore

YouTube Channels for Semester 6 Subjects:

    English: Data Science Dojo

    Hindi: IIT Delhi

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

The seventh semester focuses on emerging technologies and project work.

    Internet of Things (IoT): Principles and applications of IoT, including sensor networks and smart systems.

    Big Data Analytics: Techniques for analyzing and processing large datasets using tools and frameworks.

    Elective I: Specialized elective course in a chosen area of interest within information technology.

    Project Work I: Initial project work involving planning, research, and design in IT.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Internet of Things: Principles and Paradigms by Rajkumar Buyya

    Big Data Analytics: From Strategic Planning to Enterprise Integration by David Loshin

YouTube Channels for Semester 7 Subjects:

    English: Tech Trix

    Hindi: PadhAI

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester is dedicated to comprehensive project work, internships, and professional development.

    Major Project: A significant project involving research, development, and implementation in the field of IT.

    Industrial Training/Internship: Practical experience in an industry setting to apply theoretical knowledge.

    Elective II: Another specialized elective course in a chosen area of interest within information technology.

    Engineering Ethics and Professional Practice: Study of ethical practices, professional responsibility, and career development in IT.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Ethics by Charles E. Harris

    Project Management for Engineering by J. Nicholas

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: Tech With Tim

    Hindi: Code With Harry

Future Paths

    Software Developer: Design, develop, and maintain software applications for various platforms.

    Data Scientist: Analyze and interpret complex data to aid decision-making and strategy.

    Systems Analyst: Analyze and improve IT systems and processes to meet organizational needs.

    Network Administrator: Manage and maintain computer networks, ensuring their reliability and security.

    Cybersecurity Specialist: Protect systems and networks from cyber threats and attacks.

    Cloud Solutions Architect: Design and implement cloud computing solutions for organizations.

Preparation Tips

    Master Core Programming Skills: Develop strong programming skills in languages such as Java, Python, and C++.

    Build Practical Experience: Gain experience through internships, projects, and hands-on labs to apply theoretical knowledge.

    Stay Updated with Technologies: Keep up with the latest trends and advancements in IT, including new tools and technologies.

    Work on Soft Skills: Develop communication, teamwork, and problem-solving skills, which are crucial in IT roles.

    Participate in Coding Competitions: Engage in coding challenges and hackathons to enhance your problem-solving skills and showcase your abilities.

    Consider Certifications: Obtain relevant certifications in areas such as cloud computing, cybersecurity, and data science to boost your credentials.

Chemical Engineering

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces fundamental concepts in chemistry and engineering mathematics.

    Engineering Mathematics - I: Basic calculus, algebra, and differential equations.

    Engineering Chemistry: Fundamentals of chemistry, including chemical bonding, thermodynamics, and kinetics.

    Engineering Physics: Basics of physics including mechanics, waves, and optics.

    Introduction to Chemical Engineering: Overview of chemical engineering principles, processes, and applications.

    Basic Electrical Engineering: Introduction to electrical circuits, network theorems, and basic electronics.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Mathematics by Erwin Kreyszig

    Engineering Chemistry by Jain and Jain

    Engineering Physics by H.K. Malik

    Introduction to Chemical Engineering by J.M. Coulson and J.F. Richardson

    Basic Electrical Engineering by D.C. Kulshreshtha

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: NPTEL

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester continues with advanced chemistry topics and introduces basic engineering principles.

    Engineering Mathematics - II: Advanced calculus, partial differential equations, and linear algebra.

    Fluid Mechanics: Study of fluid properties, fluid statics and dynamics, and flow in pipelines.

    Thermodynamics: Basics of thermodynamics, including the laws of thermodynamics and thermodynamic cycles.

    Organic Chemistry: Introduction to organic compounds, reactions, and synthesis methods.

    Environmental Science: Study of environmental issues, including pollution, waste management, and sustainability.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Mathematics by Erwin Kreyszig

    Fluid Mechanics by Frank M. White

    Thermodynamics: An Engineering Approach by Yunus Çengel

    Organic Chemistry by Paula Yurkanis Bruice

    Environmental Engineering by Howard S. Peavy

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: LearnChemE

    Hindi: Khan Academy

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester focuses on core chemical engineering principles and process calculations.

    Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics: Advanced study of thermodynamics in chemical engineering applications.

    Mass Transfer Operations: Study of mass transfer principles, including distillation, absorption, and extraction.

    Heat Transfer: Fundamentals of heat transfer, including conduction, convection, and radiation.

    Chemical Reaction Engineering: Basics of chemical reaction kinetics and reactor design.

    Process Control: Introduction to process control systems, including control strategies and instrumentation.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics by Yaw’s Transport Properties of Chemicals and Hydrocarbons

    Mass Transfer Operations by Robert E. Treybal

    Heat Transfer by J.P. Holman

    Chemical Reaction Engineering by Octave Levenspiel

    Process Control: Modeling, Design, and Simulation by B. Wayne Bequette

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The fourth semester explores advanced topics in chemical engineering and industrial applications.

    Chemical Process Principles: Study of chemical process design, including process flow diagrams and material balances.

    Separation Processes: Advanced study of separation techniques such as filtration, centrifugation, and membrane processes.

    Instrumentation and Process Control: Detailed study of process instrumentation and control systems.

    Chemical Engineering Lab: Practical experiments and lab work to reinforce theoretical knowledge.

    Elective I: Specialized elective course in a chosen area of chemical engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Chemical Process Principles by Olaf A. Hougen

    Separation Process Principles by J.D. Seader and E.J. Henley

    Instrumentation for Process Measurement and Control by Norman A. Anderson

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: LearnChemE

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

The fifth semester focuses on specialized topics and advanced chemical engineering concepts.

    Chemical Engineering Design: Principles of chemical engineering design, including equipment design and process optimization.

    Petroleum Refining and Petrochemicals: Study of petroleum processing and petrochemical production.

    Biochemical Engineering: Principles of biochemical processes, including enzyme reactions and fermentation technology.

    Process Safety and Environmental Management: Study of process safety, risk assessment, and environmental management practices.

    Elective II: Another specialized elective course in chemical engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Chemical Engineering Design by Gavin Towler and Ray Sinnott

    Petroleum Refining: Technology and Economics by James H. Gary

    Biochemical Engineering Fundamentals by James E. Bailey and David F. Ollis

    Process Safety and Environmental Protection by Ian Sutton

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: LearnChemE

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

The sixth semester emphasizes advanced topics and industrial applications.

    Process Dynamics and Control: Study of dynamic behavior of processes and control strategies.

    Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics II: Advanced topics in chemical engineering thermodynamics.

    Transport Phenomena: Study of momentum, heat, and mass transfer in chemical processes.

    Chemical Engineering Lab II: Advanced experiments and practical work in chemical engineering.

    Elective III: Specialized elective course in a chosen area of chemical engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Process Dynamics and Control by Seborg, Edgar, and Mellichamp

    Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics II by Yaw’s Transport Properties of Chemicals and Hydrocarbons

    Transport Phenomena by Bird, Stewart, and Lightfoot

YouTube Channels for Semester 6 Subjects:

    English: LearnChemE

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

The seventh semester focuses on emerging technologies and project work.

    Process Optimization: Study of optimization techniques for improving chemical processes.

    Petrochemical Technology: Advanced study of petrochemical processes and products.

    Elective IV: Another specialized elective course in chemical engineering.

    Project Work I: Initial project work involving planning, research, and design in chemical engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Process Optimization: A Statistical Approach by D.C. Montgomery

    Petrochemical Technology by A. M. Gokhale

YouTube Channels for Semester 7 Subjects:

    English: LearnChemE

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester is dedicated to comprehensive project work, internships, and professional development.

    Major Project: A significant project involving research, development, and implementation in the field of chemical engineering.

    Industrial Training/Internship: Practical experience in an industry setting to apply theoretical knowledge.

    Elective V: Another specialized elective course in chemical engineering.

    Engineering Ethics and Professional Practice: Study of ethical practices, professional responsibility, and career development in chemical engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Ethics by Charles E. Harris

    Project Management for Engineering by J. Nicholas

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: LearnChemE

    Hindi: Code With Harry

Future Paths

    Chemical Engineer: Design, develop, and optimize chemical processes and equipment.

    Process Engineer: Oversee and optimize industrial processes in manufacturing and production.

    Environmental Engineer: Develop solutions for environmental issues, including pollution control and waste management.

    Petrochemical Engineer: Specialize in the production and processing of petrochemical products.

    Biochemical Engineer: Focus on biochemical processes and applications, including biotechnology and pharmaceuticals.

Preparation Tips

    Strong Fundamentals: Build a strong foundation in mathematics, chemistry, and physics.

    Hands-On Experience: Gain practical experience through internships, laboratory work, and industry projects.

    Stay Updated: Keep abreast of the latest developments and technologies in chemical engineering.

    Develop Analytical Skills: Enhance your problem-solving and analytical skills through practice and coursework.

    Participate in Research: Engage in research projects to apply theoretical knowledge to real-world problems.

Automobile Engineering

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces fundamental engineering concepts and core principles relevant to automobile engineering.

    Engineering Mathematics - I: Basic calculus, algebra, and differential equations.

    Engineering Physics: Fundamentals of physics, including mechanics, waves, and optics.

    Engineering Chemistry: Basics of chemistry, including chemical bonding, reactions, and thermodynamics.

    Engineering Graphics: Development of technical drawing skills, including orthographic and isometric projections.

    Introduction to Mechanical Engineering: Overview of mechanical engineering principles and applications.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Mathematics by Erwin Kreyszig

    Engineering Physics by H.K. Malik

    Engineering Chemistry by Jain and Jain

    Engineering Graphics by Frederick E. Giesecke

    Introduction to Mechanical Engineering by J.P. Holman

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: 3Blue1Brown

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester builds on core principles and introduces fundamental concepts in automotive systems.

    Engineering Mathematics - II: Advanced calculus, partial differential equations, and linear algebra.

    Fluid Mechanics: Study of fluid properties, fluid statics and dynamics, and flow in pipelines.

    Thermodynamics: Basics of thermodynamics, including the laws of thermodynamics and thermodynamic cycles.

    Mechanics of Materials: Study of material behavior under different forces, including stress, strain, and deformation.

    Automobile Engineering Fundamentals: Introduction to automobile systems, components, and their functions.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Mathematics by Erwin Kreyszig

    Fluid Mechanics by Frank M. White

    Thermodynamics: An Engineering Approach by Yunus Çengel

    Mechanics of Materials by Ferdinand P. Beer

    Automobile Engineering by K. K. Singh

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: LearnChemE

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester focuses on core automotive systems and engineering principles.

    Automobile Engines: Study of internal combustion engines, engine components, and performance characteristics.

    Automobile Transmission Systems: Analysis of transmission systems, including gearboxes, clutches, and differentials.

    Vehicle Dynamics: Study of vehicle motion, including suspension systems, handling, and stability.

    Heat Transfer: Fundamentals of heat transfer, including conduction, convection, and radiation, applied to automotive systems.

    Automobile Electrical Systems: Introduction to electrical systems in automobiles, including lighting, ignition, and battery systems.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Automobile Engineering by K. K. Singh

    Internal Combustion Engine Fundamentals by John B. Heywood

    Vehicle Dynamics: Theory and Application by Hanwei Wang

    Heat Transfer by J.P. Holman

    Automobile Electrical and Electronic Systems by Tom Denton

    English: Engineering Mentor

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The fourth semester delves into advanced automotive systems and applications.

    Automobile Design: Principles of designing automobile components and systems, including CAD tools and design methodologies.

    Automobile Manufacturing Technology: Study of manufacturing processes and technologies used in automobile production.

    Automobile Testing and Diagnostics: Techniques for testing and diagnosing automobile systems and performance issues.

    Emissions and Pollution Control: Study of emission control technologies and regulations to reduce vehicle pollution.

    Elective I: Specialized elective course related to automobile engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Automobile Design: Principles and Practice by David Crolla

    Automobile Manufacturing Technology by J. H. Williams

    Automobile Testing and Diagnostics by Michael G. Ball

    Emissions Control: Methods and Technology by E. B. Smith

    English: Engineering Explained

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

The fifth semester focuses on emerging technologies and advanced topics in automobile engineering.

    Advanced Vehicle Technologies: Study of advanced technologies in vehicle systems, including electric and hybrid vehicles.

    Automobile Aerodynamics: Study of aerodynamic principles and their application to automobile design for performance and efficiency.

    Automobile HVAC Systems: Study of heating, ventilation, and air conditioning systems in vehicles.

    Project Work I: Initial project work involving planning, research, and design related to automobile engineering.

    Elective II: Specialized elective course in an advanced area of automobile engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Advanced Vehicle Technology by Heinz Heisler

    Automobile Aerodynamics by Joseph Katz

    Automobile HVAC Systems by Lawrence K. Schwartz

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Explained

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

The sixth semester emphasizes practical applications and industry-oriented skills.

    Automobile Safety Systems: Study of safety systems and technologies, including airbags, ABS, and collision avoidance systems.

    Vehicle Control Systems: Study of control systems used in vehicles, including electronic stability control and adaptive cruise control.

    Automobile Materials and Manufacturing: Study of materials used in automobile construction and advanced manufacturing techniques.

    Project Work II: Continuation of the project work from Semester 5, focusing on implementation and testing.

    Elective III: Specialized elective course in a cutting-edge area of automobile engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Automobile Safety Systems by Ronald K. Jurgen

    Vehicle Control Systems by R. Isermann

    Automobile Materials and Manufacturing by A. K. Bandyopadhyay
