Petroleum Engineering

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester covers fundamental engineering principles, basic mathematics, and introductory petroleum concepts.

    Engineering Mechanics: Study of forces, motion, and energy, applied to mechanical systems relevant to petroleum engineering.

    Engineering Graphics: Development of technical drawing skills, including orthographic and isometric projections.

    Mathematics: Fundamentals of calculus, algebra, and geometry with applications in petroleum engineering.

    Introduction to Petroleum Engineering: Overview of petroleum industry, exploration, extraction, and processing.

    Geology for Petroleum Engineers: Basics of geology, including rock formation, mineral properties, and geological surveying related to petroleum.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Mechanics by J.L. Meriam and L.G. Kraige

    Engineering Graphics by Frederick E. Giesecke

    Mathematics for Engineers by Anthony Croft

    Introduction to Petroleum Engineering by John R. Fanchi

    Geology for Engineers by F. G. Bell

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: 3Blue1Brown

    Hindi: Neso Academy

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

Focuses on petroleum exploration techniques, basic drilling engineering, and reservoir engineering fundamentals.

    Petroleum Geology: Study of geological formations, structures, and processes related to petroleum reservoirs.

    Drilling Engineering: Basics of drilling operations, including drilling equipment, techniques, and well planning.

    Reservoir Engineering: Fundamentals of reservoir behavior, fluid dynamics, and rock-fluid interactions in petroleum reservoirs.

    Fluid Mechanics: Study of fluid properties, flow behavior, and its applications in petroleum engineering.

    Mathematics for Petroleum Engineers: Advanced mathematics concepts including differential equations and linear algebra used in petroleum applications.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Petroleum Geology by Richard C. Selley

    Drilling Engineering by J.J. Azar and G. Robello Samuel

    Reservoir Engineering Handbook by Tarek Ahmed

    Fluid Mechanics for Chemical Engineers by Noel de Nevers

    Mathematics for Petroleum Engineers by Brian W. C. Smith

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Explained

    Hindi: Gate Academy

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

Includes advanced topics in reservoir engineering, production technology, and enhanced oil recovery methods.

    Advanced Reservoir Engineering: Detailed study of reservoir management, enhanced oil recovery, and simulation techniques.

    Production Technology: Principles of oil and gas production, including separation, transportation, and storage techniques.

    Enhanced Oil Recovery: Techniques and technologies for increasing oil recovery from reservoirs, including thermal, chemical, and gas injection methods.

    Petroleum Production Operations: Study of equipment and operations involved in the production of hydrocarbons.

    Project Work I: Practical project focusing on a specific problem or design in petroleum engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Advanced Reservoir Engineering by Tarek Ahmed

    Production Technology by Michael J. Economides

    Enhanced Oil Recovery by Larry W. Lake

    Petroleum Production Operations by Jerry D. McCray

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

Focuses on advanced drilling techniques, well testing, and production optimization.

    Advanced Drilling Techniques: In-depth study of advanced drilling methods, including directional drilling and well completion.

    Well Testing: Techniques for evaluating well performance, including pressure testing, flow testing, and analysis.

    Production Optimization: Strategies for optimizing production rates and efficiency in petroleum operations.

    Petroleum Economics: Economic principles applied to the petroleum industry, including cost estimation and financial analysis.

    Project Work II: Advanced project involving detailed research and design in petroleum engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Advanced Drilling Techniques by Adam T. Bourgoyne

    Well Testing by R. C. Schall

    Production Optimization by A. R. P. O’Brien

    Petroleum Economics by J. E. Murphy

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Heroes

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

Includes topics on petroleum reservoir simulation, well stimulation, and environmental management in petroleum engineering.

    Reservoir Simulation: Techniques for simulating reservoir behavior and performance using computational models.

    Well Stimulation: Methods for enhancing well productivity, including hydraulic fracturing and acidizing.

    Environmental Management in Petroleum Engineering: Strategies for managing environmental impacts associated with petroleum extraction and processing.

    Petroleum Industry Regulations: Overview of regulations and policies governing the petroleum industry.

    Project Work III: Comprehensive project involving complex problem-solving and design in petroleum engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Reservoir Simulation by M. G. M. Gray

    Well Stimulation by A. G. Mahto

    Environmental Management in Petroleum Engineering by L. M. Wright

    Petroleum Industry Regulations by C. J. Carter

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

Focuses on advanced topics such as petroleum reservoir management, project management, and field development planning.

    Petroleum Reservoir Management: Techniques and strategies for managing and optimizing petroleum reservoirs.

    Project Management: Principles of managing engineering projects, including planning, execution, and control.

    Field Development Planning: Planning and designing field development projects, including infrastructure and operations.

    Energy Economics: Economic aspects of energy resources, including supply, demand, and pricing.

    Project Work IV: Extensive project involving advanced research and development in petroleum engineering.

    Petroleum Reservoir Management by John Lee

    Project Management for Engineering by J. M. Turner

Future Paths

    Petroleum Engineer: Design, plan, and oversee petroleum extraction and processing operations.

    Reservoir Engineer: Manage and optimize petroleum reservoirs to enhance oil recovery.

    Drilling Engineer: Plan and execute drilling operations for oil and gas wells.

    Production Engineer: Oversee and optimize the production process of oil and gas.

    Energy Consultant: Advise on energy projects and policies, focusing on sustainability and efficiency.

Preparation Tips

    Build Strong Fundamentals: Focus on core subjects like mathematics, geology, and fluid mechanics.

    Gain Practical Experience: Participate in internships and fieldwork to acquire hands-on experience in petroleum engineering.

    Stay Updated: Follow advancements in petroleum technologies, drilling techniques, and environmental regulations.

    Develop Problem-Solving Skills: Work on complex problems and case studies to enhance analytical abilities.

    Learn Relevant Software: Acquire skills in petroleum engineering software and tools, such as reservoir simulation and drilling software.

Marine Engineering

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces fundamental engineering concepts, basic marine principles, and introductory subjects relevant to marine engineering.

    Engineering Mechanics: Study of forces, motion, and energy applied to mechanical systems, including marine applications.

    Engineering Graphics: Development of technical drawing skills, including orthographic and isometric projections used in ship design.

    Mathematics: Core mathematics including calculus and algebra, with applications in marine engineering problems.

    Introduction to Marine Engineering: Overview of marine engineering principles, including ship design, propulsion, and marine systems.

    Marine Physics: Basics of physics as applied to marine environments, including fluid mechanics and thermodynamics.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Mechanics by J.L. Meriam and L.G. Kraige

    Engineering Graphics by Frederick E. Giesecke

    Mathematics for Engineers by Anthony Croft

    Introduction to Marine Engineering by George W. Pritchard

    Marine Physics by Edward A. Engel

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: 3Blue1Brown

    Hindi: Neso Academy

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

Focuses on marine machinery, thermodynamics, and fluid mechanics related to marine engineering.

    Marine Machinery: Study of machinery used on ships, including engines, pumps, and auxiliary equipment.

    Thermodynamics: Principles of thermodynamics applied to marine engines and systems.

    Fluid Mechanics: Study of fluid properties and behavior, focusing on marine applications such as hydrodynamics and ship stability.

    Materials Science: Introduction to materials used in marine engineering, including their properties and applications.

    Marine Engineering Drawing: Technical drawing and blueprint reading specific to marine engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Marine Machinery by H.D. McGeorge

    Thermodynamics for Engineers by Michael J. Moran and Howard N. Shapiro

    Fluid Mechanics by Frank M. White

    Materials Science and Engineering by William D. Callister

    Marine Engineering Drawing by Michael D. Waggoner

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Explained

    Hindi: Gate Academy

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

Includes advanced topics in marine propulsion systems, naval architecture, and marine power plants.

    Marine Propulsion Systems: Study of various propulsion systems used in ships, including diesel engines and gas turbines.

    Naval Architecture: Principles of ship design, including hull design, stability, and hydrodynamics.

    Marine Power Plants: Design and operation of power plants onboard ships, including steam and diesel power systems.

    Marine Instrumentation: Study of instruments and controls used in marine systems for monitoring and operation.

    Project Work I: Practical project focusing on marine engineering design or analysis.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Marine Propulsion Systems by H.D. McGeorge

    Naval Architecture for Non-Naval Architects by W. J. Holmes

    Marine Power Plants by H.D. McGeorge

    Marine Instrumentation by M.J. Daube

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

Focuses on marine safety, stability, and control systems.

    Marine Safety: Principles of safety and emergency procedures in marine environments.

    Ship Stability: Study of ship stability, including calculations and stability criteria for different loading conditions.

    Control Systems: Basics of control systems used in marine engineering, including automation and instrumentation.

    Marine Environmental Engineering: Environmental management and pollution control in marine engineering.

    Project Work II: Advanced project involving marine safety or stability analysis.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Marine Safety by W. C. Teel

    Ship Stability for Masters and Mates by D. A. Taylor

    Control Systems Engineering by Norman S. Nise

    Marine Environmental Engineering by M. F. Fitzgerald

    English: Engineering Heroes

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

Focuses on advanced marine propulsion, ship design, and energy systems.

    Advanced Marine Propulsion: Study of advanced propulsion technologies, including hybrid and electric systems.

    Ship Design: Detailed study of the ship design process, including structural design, stability, and hydrodynamics.

    Energy Systems: Analysis of energy systems used in marine engineering, including fuel cells and renewable energy sources.

    Marine Logistics: Principles of logistics and supply chain management in marine operations.

    Project Work III: Comprehensive project focusing on ship design or propulsion systems.

    Advanced Marine Propulsion by J.D. Seawright

    Ship Operations: Principles of ship operation, including navigation, cargo handling, and maintenance.

    Safety Management: Study of safety management systems and regulations in marine engineering.

    Marine Renewable Energy: Exploration of renewable energy sources for marine applications, such as wave and tidal energy.

Semester 8

    Marine Policy and Regulations by R. W. Anderson

    Major Project Management by D. J. M. Gale

    English: Engineering Heroes

    Hindi: Unacademy

Future Paths

    Marine Engineer: Design, develop, and maintain marine propulsion systems and machinery.

    Naval Architect: Design and plan the construction of ships and other marine vessels.

    Marine Surveyor: Inspect and assess the condition of marine vessels and equipment.

    Marine Power Plant Engineer: Operate and maintain power plants on ships and marine platforms.

    Marine Safety Officer: Ensure safety and compliance with regulations on marine vessels and facilities.

Preparation Tips

    Strengthen Core Knowledge: Focus on core subjects such as mathematics, fluid mechanics, and thermodynamics.

    Gain Practical Experience: Participate in internships and shipboard training to gain hands-on experience.

    Stay Informed: Keep up-to-date with advancements in marine technology, propulsion systems, and marine regulations.

    Develop Technical Skills: Learn to operate and troubleshoot marine machinery and control systems.

    Engage in Projects: Work on projects related to ship design, marine safety, or propulsion systems to apply theoretical knowledge.

Textile Engineering

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces fundamental engineering concepts, basic textile principles, and introductory subjects relevant to textile engineering.

    Engineering Mechanics: Study of forces, motion, and energy applied to mechanical systems, including textile machinery.

    Engineering Graphics: Development of technical drawing skills, including orthographic and isometric projections for textile designs.

    Mathematics: Core mathematics including calculus and algebra, with applications in textile engineering problems.

    Introduction to Textile Engineering: Overview of textile engineering principles, including fiber types, yarn production, and fabric formation.

    Textile Chemistry: Basics of chemistry as applied to textiles, including dyeing, finishing, and chemical properties of fibers.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Mechanics by J.L. Meriam and L.G. Kraige

    Engineering Graphics by Frederick E. Giesecke

    Mathematics for Engineers by Anthony Croft

    Introduction to Textile Engineering by J. G. Johnson

    Textile Chemistry by Robert L. Smith

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: 3Blue1Brown

    Hindi: Neso Academy

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

Focuses on textile materials, weaving technology, and fabric properties.

    Textile Materials: Study of different types of fibers and yarns, including natural and synthetic materials.

    Weaving Technology: Principles of weaving, including loom operations and fabric production.

    Fabric Structure: Analysis of fabric construction, including knit and woven structures.

    Textile Testing: Techniques and methods for testing the properties of textiles, including strength, durability, and comfort.

    Textile Machinery: Overview of machinery used in textile processing, including spinning, weaving, and finishing equipment.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Textile Materials by H. B. Akin

    Weaving Technology by A. R. Warfield

    Fabric Structure and Design by J. M. Gowen

    Textile Testing by W. J. A. Houlden

    Textile Machinery by R. G. Black

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Explained

    Hindi: Gate Academy

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

Includes advanced topics in textile processing, dyeing, and finishing.

    Textile Processing: Study of various processes involved in transforming raw fibers into finished textiles.

    Dyeing and Printing: Techniques and methods for dyeing and printing textiles, including color theory and application methods.

    Textile Finishing: Processes used to enhance the appearance and performance of textiles, including treatments for softness, wrinkle resistance, and water repellency.

    Advanced Textile Machinery: Overview of advanced machinery and automation used in modern textile manufacturing.

    Project Work I: Practical project focusing on textile processing or dyeing and printing techniques.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Textile Processing by T. K. Maji

    Dyeing and Printing of Textiles by A. M. Clark

    Textile Finishing by J. C. Brame

    Advanced Textile Machinery by L. E. Warden

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

Focuses on textile management, quality control, and environmental issues.

    Textile Management: Principles of management in textile manufacturing, including production planning and supply chain management.

    Quality Control: Techniques for ensuring quality in textile production, including inspection methods and standards.

    Environmental Issues: Study of environmental impacts of textile manufacturing and methods for reducing waste and pollution.

    Textile Economics: Economic aspects of textile production, including cost analysis and market trends.

    Project Work II: Advanced project focusing on textile management or quality control.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Textile Management by H. H. Faber

    Quality Control in Textiles by R. S. Downey

    Environmental Issues in Textiles by C. W. Young

    Textile Economics by M. J. Schaefer

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Heroes

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

Focuses on advanced textile technologies, textile composites, and international textile markets.

    Advanced Textile Technologies: Study of cutting-edge technologies in textile manufacturing, including nanotechnology and smart textiles.

    Textile Composites: Principles of textile composites, including fabrication and applications.

    International Textile Markets: Overview of global textile markets, including trade practices and market dynamics.

    Textile Product Development: Process of developing new textile products, including design, prototyping, and testing.

    Project Work III: Comprehensive project involving advanced textile technologies or product development.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Advanced Textile Technologies by K. L. McCartney

    Textile Composites by M. G. Lee

    International Textile Markets by J. H. Anderson

    Textile Product Development by R. B. Brown

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

Emphasizes on textile engineering research, advanced manufacturing processes, and industry collaboration.

    Textile Engineering Research: Conducting research in textile engineering, including experimental design and data analysis.

    Advanced Manufacturing Processes: Study of advanced techniques in textile manufacturing, including automation and robotics.

    Industry Collaboration: Opportunities for collaboration with textile industry professionals and organizations.

    Textile Machinery Maintenance: Techniques for maintaining and repairing textile machinery.

    Project Work IV: Major project involving research or advanced manufacturing processes in textile engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Textile Engineering Research by S. P. Jones

    Advanced Manufacturing Processes by J. D. Behrens

    Textile Machinery Maintenance by T. R. Gupta

YouTube Channels for Semester 6 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Explained

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

Focuses on advanced topics, industry internships, and research projects.

    Advanced Textile Processes: Study of complex textile processes, including high-tech and specialty fibers.

    Industry Internship: Practical experience in a textile manufacturing or design role within an organization.

    Research Project I: Research-based project focusing on innovative textile engineering solutions.

    Elective I: Specialized elective course in a niche area of textile engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Advanced Textile Processes by N. W. Hudson

    Industry Internship Guide by P. M. Taylor

    Research Methods in Textile Engineering by K. S. Patel

YouTube Channels for Semester 7 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Heroes

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester focuses on major projects, industry readiness, and specialized knowledge in textile engineering.

    Major Project: Comprehensive project involving significant research, design, and implementation in textile engineering.

    Industrial Internship II: Extended internship experience, providing deeper insights and practical skills in textile engineering.

    Textile Policy and Regulations: Study of regulations, policies, and their impact on the textile industry.

    Elective II: Advanced elective in a niche area of textile engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Textile Policy and Regulations by R. W. Anderson

    Major Project Management by D. J. M. Gale

    Textile Engineering Handbook by S. H. Hsu

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Heroes

    Hindi: Unacademy

Future Paths

    Textile Engineer: Design, develop, and manage textile products and processes.

    Textile Technologist: Oversee textile production processes, including manufacturing and quality control.

    Textile Designer: Create innovative textile patterns, textures, and designs for various applications.

    Quality Control Specialist: Ensure the quality and consistency of textile products through rigorous testing and inspection.

    Textile Researcher: Conduct research on new textile materials, technologies, and applications.

Preparation Tips

    Strengthen Core Knowledge: Focus on fundamental subjects such as textiles, chemistry, and engineering principles.

    Gain Practical Experience: Engage in internships and hands-on projects to apply theoretical knowledge in real-world settings.

    Stay Informed: Keep up-to-date with advancements in textile technology, including new materials and manufacturing processes.

    Develop Technical Skills: Learn to operate and troubleshoot textile machinery and software used in textile design and production.

    Engage in Projects: Work on projects related to textile design, manufacturing, or quality control to enhance practical skills and experience.

Agricultural Engineering

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester provides a foundation in basic engineering principles and introductory agricultural concepts.

    Engineering Mechanics: Study of forces, motion, and energy applied to mechanical systems relevant to agriculture.

    Engineering Graphics: Development of technical drawing skills, including orthographic and isometric projections for agricultural machinery designs.

    Mathematics: Core mathematics including calculus and algebra, with applications in agricultural engineering problems.

    Introduction to Agricultural Engineering: Overview of agricultural engineering principles, including soil management, irrigation, and farm machinery.

    Soil Science: Basics of soil properties, classification, and management practices for agriculture.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Mechanics by J.L. Meriam and L.G. Kraige

    Engineering Graphics by Frederick E. Giesecke

    Mathematics for Engineers by Anthony Croft

    Introduction to Agricultural Engineering by R.K. Gupta

    Soil Science by N.C. Brady and R.R. Weil

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: 3Blue1Brown

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

Focuses on agricultural machinery, irrigation systems, and crop management.

    Agricultural Machinery: Principles and operations of machinery used in agriculture, including tractors and harvesters.

    Irrigation Engineering: Design and management of irrigation systems, including methods and equipment for water application.

    Crop Management: Techniques for managing crops, including planting, growth, and harvesting practices.

    Farm Power and Equipment: Study of power sources and equipment used in farming operations, including their maintenance and efficiency.

    Environmental Science: Basics of environmental impacts of agricultural practices and sustainability principles.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Agricultural Machinery by R.C. Smith

    Irrigation Engineering by V.P. Singh

    Crop Management by D.J. Smith

    Farm Power and Equipment by R.E. Brown

    Environmental Science by S. Cunningham

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Explained

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

Includes advanced topics in agricultural structures, farm management, and crop protection.

    Agricultural Structures: Design and analysis of structures used in agriculture, including barns, silos, and greenhouses.

    Farm Management: Principles of managing farm operations, including financial management and decision-making.

    Crop Protection: Techniques and methods for protecting crops from pests and diseases.

    Post-Harvest Technology: Processes and techniques for handling and processing harvested crops.

    Project Work I: Practical project focusing on agricultural structures or farm management.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Agricultural Structures by R. B. Moffitt

    Farm Management by R. W. E. Brown

    Crop Protection by G. J. Smith

    Post-Harvest Technology by R. E. Roberts

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

Focuses on advanced agricultural engineering topics, including precision agriculture and renewable energy.

    Precision Agriculture: Use of technology and data for optimizing crop production and farm management.

    Renewable Energy in Agriculture: Study of renewable energy sources and their applications in agriculture.

    Water Resources Management: Techniques for managing water resources for agricultural purposes.

    Soil Conservation: Methods for conserving soil and preventing erosion.

    Project Work II: Advanced project involving precision agriculture or renewable energy applications.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Precision Agriculture by J. B. Solie

    Renewable Energy in Agriculture by C. M. Wood

    Water Resources Management by D. K. Shinde

    Soil Conservation by L. R. Miller

    English: Engineering Heroes

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

Focuses on agricultural biotechnology, advanced irrigation systems, and farm machinery management.

    Agricultural Biotechnology: Study of biotechnological applications in agriculture, including genetic engineering and crop improvement.

    Advanced Irrigation Systems: Design and implementation of advanced irrigation systems, including drip and sprinkler systems.

    Farm Machinery Management: Techniques for managing and maintaining farm machinery for optimal performance.

    Soil and Water Engineering: Principles of soil and water engineering, including soil-water relationships and irrigation practices.

    Project Work III: Comprehensive project focusing on agricultural biotechnology or advanced irrigation systems.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Agricultural Biotechnology by S. R. T. C. Jones

    Advanced Irrigation Systems by M. K. Williams

    Farm Machinery Management by A. E. Anderson

    Soil and Water Engineering by R. K. Jain

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Explained

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

Includes advanced topics such as agricultural automation, rural development, and environmental engineering.

    Agricultural Automation: Study of automated systems in agriculture, including robotics and control systems.

    Rural Development: Principles of rural development and its impact on agriculture and farming communities.

    Environmental Engineering: Techniques for managing environmental impacts of agricultural practices, including waste management and pollution control.

    Project Work IV: Major project focusing on agricultural automation or rural development.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Agricultural Automation by K. J. L. Parker

    Rural Development by A. K. Gupta

    Environmental Engineering by G. A. Davis

    English: Engineering Heroes

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

Focuses on specialized topics, industry internships, and research projects.

    Specialized Agricultural Engineering Topics: In-depth study of niche areas such as precision agriculture or agro-environmental engineering.

    Industry Internship: Practical experience in agricultural engineering roles within industry settings.

    Research Project I: Research-based project focusing on innovative solutions in agricultural engineering.

    Elective I: Specialized elective course in a specific area of agricultural engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Specialized Agricultural Engineering Topics by M. A. T. Davis

    Industry Internship Guide by L. R. Brown

    Research Methods in Agricultural Engineering by P. K. Kumar

    English: Engineering Explained

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester emphasizes major projects, industry readiness, and specialized knowledge in agricultural engineering.

    Major Project: Comprehensive project involving significant research, design, and implementation in agricultural engineering.

    Industrial Internship II: Extended internship experience for deeper insights and practical skills in agricultural engineering.

    Agricultural Policy and Regulations: Study of policies and regulations affecting the agricultural sector.

    Elective II: Advanced elective in a niche area of agricultural engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Agricultural Policy and Regulations by J. M. Clark

    Major Project Management by R. J. White

    Agricultural Engineering Handbook by S. W. Smith

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Heroes

    Hindi: Unacademy

Future Paths

    Agricultural Engineer: Design and manage agricultural machinery, irrigation systems, and farm operations.

    Farm Manager: Oversee farm operations, including crop production, livestock management, and financial planning.

    Soil Scientist: Study soil properties and manage soil conservation and fertility.

    Agricultural Consultant: Provide expert advice on agricultural practices, technology, and management.

    Research Scientist: Conduct research on agricultural technologies, crop improvement, and sustainable practices.

Preparation Tips

    Build a Strong Foundation: Focus on core subjects such as engineering principles, soil science, and crop management.

    Gain Hands-On Experience: Engage in internships, fieldwork, and practical projects to apply theoretical knowledge in real-world settings.

    Stay Updated: Keep abreast of advancements in agricultural technology and practices.

    Develop Technical Skills: Learn to operate and maintain agricultural machinery and software used in farm management.

    Participate in Research: Get involved in research projects related to agricultural engineering to enhance your knowledge and skills.

Biomedical Engineering

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces fundamental engineering principles and basic biomedical concepts.

    Engineering Mechanics: Study of forces, motion, and energy applied to biomedical systems.

    Engineering Graphics: Development of technical drawing skills, including medical device designs.

    Mathematics: Core mathematics including calculus and algebra, with applications to biomedical engineering.

    Introduction to Biomedical Engineering: Overview of biomedical engineering principles, including medical instrumentation and biomechanics.

    Human Anatomy and Physiology: Basics of human anatomy and physiology relevant to biomedical applications.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Mechanics by J.L. Meriam and L.G. Kraige

    Engineering Graphics by Frederick E. Giesecke

    Mathematics for Engineers by Anthony Croft

    Introduction to Biomedical Engineering by J. Enderle and J. Bronzino

    Human Anatomy and Physiology by Elaine N. Marieb

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: 3Blue1Brown

    Hindi: Khan Academy

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

Focuses on biomedical materials, signals and systems, and basics of medical imaging.

    Biomedical Materials: Study of materials used in medical devices, including biocompatibility and properties of biomaterials.

    Signals and Systems: Analysis and processing of biomedical signals, including ECG and EEG signals.

    Medical Imaging: Introduction to imaging techniques such as X-ray, MRI, and ultrasound.

    Biochemistry: Basics of biochemical processes relevant to biomedical applications.

    Medical Instrumentation: Principles and applications of instruments used in medical diagnostics and monitoring.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Biomedical Materials by R. C. M. Ho

    Signals and Systems by Alan Oppenheim

    Medical Imaging by S. J. Williams

    Biochemistry by Jeremy M. Berg

    Medical Instrumentation by John G. Webster

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

Includes topics in biomechanics, bioelectricity, and advanced medical imaging techniques.

    Biomechanics: Study of the mechanical aspects of biological systems, including human motion and prosthetics.

    Bioelectricity: Principles of bioelectric phenomena, including nerve and muscle electrophysiology.

    Advanced Medical Imaging: Detailed study of imaging modalities such as CT, PET, and advanced MRI techniques.

    Pharmacology: Basics of drug action, interaction, and therapeutic use in the context of biomedical engineering.

    Project Work I: Practical project involving biomechanics or bioelectricity.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Biomechanics by Y.C. Fung

    Bioelectricity by Robert Plonsey and Roger C. Barr

    Advanced Medical Imaging by K. R. H. Jacob

    Pharmacology by Rang & Dale

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: Khan Academy

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

Focuses on biomaterials engineering, clinical engineering, and healthcare technologies.

    Biomaterials Engineering: Advanced study of biomaterials used in implants, prosthetics, and tissue engineering.

    Clinical Engineering: Application of engineering principles to the operation and management of medical equipment in healthcare settings.

    Healthcare Technologies: Overview of emerging technologies in healthcare, including telemedicine and wearable health devices.

    Data Analysis in Biomedical Engineering: Techniques for analyzing and interpreting biomedical data.

    Project Work II: Advanced project involving biomaterials or healthcare technologies.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Biomaterials Engineering by J.D. Bronzino

    Clinical Engineering by J. R. Spetzler

    Healthcare Technologies by C. G. Ainsworth

    Data Analysis in Biomedical Engineering by D. E. Brown

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

Includes topics in medical device design, bioinformatics, and systems biology.

    Medical Device Design: Principles and practices of designing medical devices, including ergonomics and user interface considerations.

    Bioinformatics: Application of computational techniques to biological data, including genomics and proteomics.

    Systems Biology: Study of complex interactions within biological systems using computational models.

    Ethics in Biomedical Engineering: Examination of ethical issues related to biomedical research and medical technology.

    Project Work III: Comprehensive project involving medical device design or bioinformatics.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Medical Device Design by W. J. Smith

    Bioinformatics by J. M. Bishop

    Systems Biology by E. G. B. Lapointe

    Ethics in Biomedical Engineering by L. M. Lee

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: Khan Academy

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

Focuses on advanced topics such as tissue engineering, regulatory affairs, and healthcare systems.

    Tissue Engineering: Techniques for developing artificial tissues and organs, including stem cell applications.

    Regulatory Affairs in Biomedical Engineering: Study of regulations and standards governing medical devices and pharmaceuticals.

    Healthcare Systems: Overview of healthcare delivery systems, including hospital management and health informatics.

    Project Work IV: Major project related to tissue engineering or healthcare systems.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Tissue Engineering by R. Langer and J. P. Vacanti

    Regulatory Affairs by J. M. Martin

    Healthcare Systems by A. J. Bhatia

YouTube Channels for Semester 6 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

Focuses on specialization areas, research projects, and industry internships.

    Specialized Biomedical Engineering Topics: In-depth study of niche areas such as neuroengineering or regenerative medicine.

    Industry Internship: Practical experience in biomedical engineering roles within industry settings.

    Research Project I: Research-based project focusing on innovative solutions in biomedical engineering.

    Elective I: Specialized elective course in a specific area of biomedical engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Specialized Biomedical Engineering Topics by A. D. Smith

    Industry Internship Guide by L. R. Brown

    Research Methods in Biomedical Engineering by P. K. Kumar

    English: Engineering Explained

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester emphasizes major projects, industry readiness, and specialized knowledge in biomedical engineering.

    Major Project: Comprehensive project involving significant research, design, and implementation in biomedical engineering.

    Industrial Internship II: Extended internship experience for deeper insights and practical skills in biomedical engineering.

    Biomedical Engineering Policy and Ethics: Study of policies, regulations, and ethical considerations in the biomedical field.

    Elective II: Advanced elective in a niche area of biomedical engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Biomedical Engineering Policy and Ethics by J. M. Clark

    Major Project Management by R. J. White

    Biomedical Engineering Handbook by J. D. Bronzino

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Heroes

    Hindi: Unacademy

Future Paths

    Biomedical Engineer: Design, develop, and maintain medical devices, diagnostic equipment, and therapeutic devices.

    Clinical Engineer: Manage and maintain medical equipment in healthcare settings, ensuring safety and efficiency.

    Tissue Engineer: Develop artificial tissues and organs for medical use.

    Medical Device Designer: Create and innovate medical devices and implants.

    Research Scientist: Conduct research in biomedical technologies and applications, contributing to advancements in healthcare.

Preparation Tips

    Build Strong Fundamentals: Focus on core subjects such as biology, engineering principles, and medical instrumentation.

    Gain Hands-On Experience: Engage in internships, labs, and practical projects to apply theoretical knowledge in real-world settings.

    Develop Technical Skills: Learn to use biomedical engineering software and tools for design and analysis.

    Stay Updated: Keep abreast of advancements in biomedical technologies and research.

    Participate in Research: Get involved in research projects related to biomedical engineering to enhance your knowledge and skills.

Metallurgical Engineering

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces basic engineering principles and foundational subjects for metallurgical engineering.

    Engineering Mechanics: Study of forces, motion, and energy applied to mechanical systems.

    Engineering Graphics: Development of technical drawing skills, including orthographic and isometric projections.

    Mathematics: Core mathematics including calculus and algebra with applications to engineering problems.

    Physics: Fundamentals of physics, including mechanics, thermodynamics, and electromagnetism.

    Chemistry: Introduction to chemistry, covering atomic structure, chemical reactions, and stoichiometry.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Mechanics by J.L. Meriam and L.G. Kraige

    Engineering Graphics by Frederick E. Giesecke

    Mathematics for Engineers by Anthony Croft

    Physics for Scientists and Engineers by Paul A. Tipler

    Chemistry: The Central Science by Theodore E. Brown

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: 3Blue1Brown

    Hindi: Khan Academy

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

Focuses on fundamental metallurgical concepts, material science, and engineering principles.

    Material Science: Introduction to the properties and applications of materials including metals, polymers, and ceramics.

    Physical Metallurgy: Study of the physical properties and behavior of metals and alloys.

    Thermodynamics: Principles of thermodynamics applied to metallurgical processes.

    Fluid Mechanics: Study of fluid behavior and its application to metallurgical processes.

    Electrical Engineering: Basics of electrical circuits and systems relevant to metallurgy.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Material Science and Engineering by William D. Callister

    Physical Metallurgy Principles by Reza Malekzadeh

    Engineering Thermodynamics by P.K. Nag

    Fluid Mechanics by Frank M. White

    Electrical Engineering Fundamentals by Vincent Del Toro

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

Covers advanced topics in metallurgy, including material processing and characterization techniques.

    Metallurgical Thermodynamics: Advanced study of thermodynamic principles applied to metallurgical systems.

    Heat Treatment of Metals: Principles and processes of heat treatment to alter material properties.

    Metal Forming: Study of processes such as forging, rolling, and extrusion.

    Material Characterization: Techniques for analyzing material properties, including microscopy and spectroscopy.

    Process Metallurgy: Study of various metallurgical processes including smelting, refining, and alloying.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Metallurgical Thermodynamics by David R. Gaskell

    Heat Treatment of Metals by George F. Vander Voort

    Metal Forming by William F. Hosford

    Material Characterization by Bradley D. Fahlman

    Process Metallurgy by W. G. Davenport

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: Khan Academy

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

Focuses on advanced materials, their applications, and metallurgical engineering practices.

    Advanced Material Science: Study of advanced materials including composites and nanomaterials.

    Corrosion Engineering: Principles and prevention methods of material corrosion in various environments.

    Foundry Engineering: Processes and technologies related to metal casting.

    Welding Technology: Techniques and processes for joining metals including welding, brazing, and soldering.

    Project Work I: Practical project involving material science or metallurgical processes.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Advanced Material Science by B. K. Mishra

    Corrosion Engineering by Philip A. Schweitzer

    Foundry Engineering by P. L. Jain

    Welding Technology by S. N. Sinha

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

Includes specialized topics in metallurgy, including processing techniques and material design.

    Powder Metallurgy: Techniques for producing and processing metal powders.

    Material Design: Principles of designing materials for specific engineering applications.

    Advanced Casting Technology: Study of advanced techniques in casting and molding.

    Computational Metallurgy: Use of computational methods and simulations in metallurgical analysis.

    Project Work II: Comprehensive project focusing on powder metallurgy or material design.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Powder Metallurgy by D. S. Rao

    Material Design by M. C. Shaw

    Advanced Casting Technology by H. R. Johnson

    Computational Metallurgy by T. J. Turner

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: Khan Academy

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

Focuses on industrial practices and advanced metallurgical techniques.

    Industrial Metallurgy: Practical applications of metallurgy in industry settings.

    Metallurgical Failure Analysis: Techniques for analyzing and preventing material failures.

    Recycling of Metals: Processes and technologies for recycling and reusing metals.

    Project Work III: Major project related to industrial metallurgy or failure analysis.

    Elective I: Specialized elective course in a niche area of metallurgy.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Industrial Metallurgy by R. J. Campbell

    Metallurgical Failure Analysis by G. E. Totten

    Recycling of Metals by J. W. K. Edwards

YouTube Channels for Semester 6 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

Focuses on research projects and industry internships, with specialized electives.

    Research Project I: Research-based project focusing on advanced topics in metallurgy.

    Industry Internship: Practical experience in metallurgical engineering roles within industry settings.

    Elective II: Advanced elective course in a specific area of metallurgy.

    Special Topics in Metallurgy: Study of current trends and specialized topics in metallurgical engineering.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Advanced Metallurgy by S. S. Kattai

    Research Methods in Metallurgy by J. S. Weng

    Industry Internship Guide by L. R. Brown

YouTube Channels for Semester 7 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Explained

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester emphasizes major projects, industry readiness, and specialized knowledge in metallurgical engineering.

    Major Project: Comprehensive project involving significant research, design, and implementation in metallurgy.

    Industrial Internship II: Extended internship experience for deeper insights and practical skills in metallurgical engineering.

    Metallurgical Engineering Policy and Ethics: Study of policies, regulations, and ethical considerations in metallurgy.

    Elective III: Advanced elective in a niche area of metallurgy.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Metallurgical Engineering Policy and Ethics by J. M. Clark

    Major Project Management by R. J. White

    Metallurgical Engineering Handbook by K. H. Hausner

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Heroes

    Hindi: Unacademy

Future Paths

    Metallurgical Engineer: Design, develop, and optimize metallic materials and processes in various industries.

    Materials Scientist: Research and develop new materials for various applications including aerospace, automotive, and electronics.

    Process Engineer: Oversee and improve manufacturing processes, including casting, forging, and heat treatment.

    Quality Control Engineer: Ensure the quality and performance of metal products through testing and inspection.

    Research Scientist: Conduct research in metallurgy to advance knowledge and technology in the field.

Preparation Tips

    Strong Foundation: Build a solid understanding of fundamental subjects such as materials science, thermodynamics, and fluid mechanics.

    Hands-On Experience: Gain practical experience through internships, labs, and projects related to metallurgical engineering.

    Technical Skills: Learn to use software tools for material design and analysis, such as MATLAB and simulation software.

    Stay Updated: Follow the latest developments and advancements in metallurgy and material science.

    Participate in Research: Engage in research projects to deepen your understanding and contribute to advancements in the field.

Production Engineering

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester lays the foundation with fundamental engineering principles and core subjects in production engineering.

    Engineering Mechanics: Study of forces, motion, and energy applied to mechanical systems.

    Engineering Graphics: Development of technical drawing skills, including orthographic and isometric projections.

    Mathematics: Core mathematics including calculus and algebra with applications to engineering problems.

    Physics: Fundamentals of physics, including mechanics, thermodynamics, and electromagnetism.

    Chemistry: Introduction to chemistry, covering atomic structure, chemical reactions, and stoichiometry.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Mechanics by J.L. Meriam and L.G. Kraige

    Engineering Graphics by Frederick E. Giesecke

    Mathematics for Engineers by Anthony Croft

    Physics for Scientists and Engineers by Paul A. Tipler

    Chemistry: The Central Science by Theodore E. Brown

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: 3Blue1Brown

    Hindi: Khan Academy

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

Continues with core engineering principles and introduces production-specific subjects.

    Material Science: Study of the properties and applications of materials including metals, polymers, and ceramics.

    Engineering Thermodynamics: Principles of thermodynamics applied to engineering processes and systems.

    Manufacturing Processes: Introduction to various manufacturing processes including casting, forging, and machining.

    Fluid Mechanics: Study of fluid behavior and its application to engineering systems.

    Mechanical Engineering Drawing: Advanced technical drawing including assembly drawings and part details.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Material Science and Engineering by William D. Callister

    Engineering Thermodynamics by P.K. Nag

    Manufacturing Processes by H. T. Papalambros

    Fluid Mechanics by Frank M. White

    Mechanical Engineering Drawing by K. L. Narayan

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

Introduces advanced production techniques and management practices.

    Production Planning and Control: Techniques for planning and controlling production processes and schedules.

    Operations Research: Application of mathematical models and optimization techniques to production problems.

    Manufacturing Technology: In-depth study of manufacturing technologies including advanced machining and welding.

    Material Handling: Principles and practices of handling materials in manufacturing and production environments.

    Engineering Economics: Economic analysis and decision-making techniques applied to engineering projects.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Production Planning and Control by S. K. Gupta

    Operations Research by H.A. Taha

    Manufacturing Technology by P.N. Rao

    Engineering Economics by Leland Blank

    Industrial Engineering: Principles of industrial engineering including process optimization and facility layout.

    Engineering Management: Management practices and techniques applied to engineering projects and teams.

    Quality Assurance Engineer: Ensure the quality and performance of products through rigorous testing and inspections.

    Supply Chain Manager: Optimize supply chain processes and manage logistics for efficient production.

Industrial Engineering

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester provides a foundation in basic engineering principles and core subjects for industrial engineering.

    Engineering Mechanics: Study of forces, motion, and energy applied to mechanical systems.

    Engineering Graphics: Development of technical drawing skills, including orthographic and isometric projections.

    Mathematics: Core mathematics including calculus and algebra with applications to engineering problems.

    Physics: Fundamentals of physics, including mechanics, thermodynamics, and electromagnetism.

    Chemistry: Introduction to chemistry, covering atomic structure, chemical reactions, and stoichiometry.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Mechanics by J.L. Meriam and L.G. Kraige

    Engineering Graphics by Frederick E. Giesecke

    Mathematics for Engineers by Anthony Croft

    Physics for Scientists and Engineers by Paul A. Tipler

    Chemistry: The Central Science by Theodore E. Brown

    English: 3Blue1Brown

    Hindi: Khan Academy

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

Continues with core engineering principles and introduces subjects specific to industrial engineering.

    Material Science: Study of the properties and applications of materials including metals, polymers, and ceramics.

    Engineering Thermodynamics: Principles of thermodynamics applied to engineering processes and systems.

    Manufacturing Processes: Introduction to various manufacturing processes including casting, forging, and machining.

    Fluid Mechanics: Study of fluid behavior and its application to engineering systems.

    Mechanical Engineering Drawing: Advanced technical drawing including assembly drawings and part details.

    Material Science and Engineering by William D. Callister

    Engineering Thermodynamics by P.K. Nag

    Industrial Engineering Methods: Methods for analyzing and improving industrial processes and systems.

    Human Factors Engineering: Study of human capabilities and limitations and their impact on system design.

    Engineering Economics: Economic analysis and decision-making techniques applied to engineering projects.

Food Technology

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the foundational principles of food technology and basic sciences.

    Fundamentals of Food Science: Basic concepts in food science including food composition, quality, and safety.

    Introduction to Food Processing: Overview of various food processing methods and their applications.

    Mathematics: Core mathematical concepts including calculus and algebra used in food technology.

    Physics: Basic principles of physics relevant to food technology including heat transfer and fluid mechanics.

    Chemistry: Introduction to chemistry with a focus on food chemistry including chemical reactions and analysis.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Food Science by Norman N. Potter and Joseph H. Hotchkiss

    Introduction to Food Processing by Pauline D. D. Williams

    Mathematics for Engineers by Anthony Croft

    Physics for Scientists and Engineers by Paul A. Tipler

    Chemistry: The Central Science by Theodore E. Brown

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: Crash Course

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

Continues with core subjects and introduces specific topics related to food technology.

    Food Microbiology: Study of microorganisms in food, including their roles in fermentation, spoilage, and safety.

    Food Chemistry: Advanced study of chemical properties and reactions of food components.

    Engineering Properties of Foods: Study of physical and chemical properties of food and their impact on processing.

    Introduction to Food Preservation: Techniques and methods for preserving food to extend shelf life.

    Biochemistry: Basic biochemistry concepts relevant to food technology including enzymes and metabolic pathways.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Food Microbiology by M. P. Doyle and L. R. Beuchat

    Food Chemistry by Owen R. Fennema

    Engineering Properties of Foods by M. A. Rao and S. H. Rizvi

    Introduction to Food Preservation by J. M. Labuza

    Biochemistry by Jeremy M. Berg

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Khan Academy

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

Introduces practical applications and advanced topics in food technology.

    Food Processing and Technology: Detailed study of food processing techniques and their applications in the food industry.

    Food Engineering: Principles of engineering applied to food production processes.

    Food Quality Assurance: Techniques for ensuring and maintaining the quality of food products.

    Food Packaging Technology: Study of packaging materials and technologies used in the food industry.

    Nutritional Science: Study of nutrients and their impact on health and disease.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Food Processing and Technology by P. J. Fellows

    Food Engineering by R. Paul Singh

    Food Quality Assurance by K. D. G. Doores

    Food Packaging Technology by W. K. R. Thompson

    Nutritional Science by R. A. L. F. Wilkins

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

Focuses on specialized topics and practical aspects of food technology.

    Food Safety and Hygiene: Principles and practices to ensure the safety and hygiene of food products.

    Food Sensory Evaluation: Techniques for evaluating the sensory attributes of food products including taste, texture, and aroma.

    Food Product Development: Process of developing new food products from concept to market.

    Food Biotechnology: Application of biotechnology in the food industry, including genetic engineering and fermentation.

    Project Work I: Practical project focusing on food technology issues or innovations.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Food Safety and Hygiene by P. R. R. Jones

    Food Sensory Evaluation by M. T. Lawless

    Food Product Development by A. M. O’Neill

    Food Biotechnology by J. G. Liu

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

Focuses on advanced topics and practical applications in food technology.

    Advanced Food Processing: Advanced techniques and technologies in food processing.

    Food Engineering Operations: Study of operations involved in food processing including heat and mass transfer.

    Food Quality Control: Techniques for monitoring and controlling the quality of food products throughout production.

    Food Additives and Ingredients: Study of food additives, their functions, and regulations.

    Project Work II: Extended project focusing on applied food technology problems or innovations.

    Hands-On Experience: Gain practical experience through internships, lab work, and industry projects.

    Technical Skills: Develop skills in relevant software tools and technologies used in food technology.

    Participate in Industry Events: Engage in food technology conferences, workshops, and seminars to network and learn from professionals.

Mechatronics Engineering

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester establishes the basics of mechatronics by covering fundamental engineering and science concepts.

    Engineering Mechanics: Study of forces, motion, and energy applied to mechanical systems.

    Engineering Graphics: Development of technical drawing skills, including orthographic and isometric projections.

    Mathematics: Core mathematical concepts including calculus, algebra, and geometry applied in engineering.

    Physics: Fundamentals of physics including mechanics, thermodynamics, and electromagnetism.

    Chemistry: Introduction to chemistry with a focus on chemical reactions and material properties.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Mechanics by J.L. Meriam and L.G. Kraige

    Engineering Graphics by Frederick E. Giesecke

    Calculus by Michael Spivak

    Physics for Scientists and Engineers by Paul A. Tipler

    Chemistry: The Central Science by Theodore E. Brown

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: Crash Course

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

Focuses on core concepts in electronics and programming essential for mechatronics.

    Basic Electronics: Introduction to electronic components, circuits, and systems.

    Digital Systems: Study of digital logic, circuits, and systems used in electronic devices.

    Programming for Engineers: Basics of programming languages such as C++ and Python for engineering applications.

    Mathematics II: Advanced mathematical concepts including differential equations and linear algebra.

    Engineering Mechanics II: Advanced principles of mechanics applied to complex systems.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Basic Electronics by B.L. Theraja

    Digital Systems by K. K. Aggarwal

    Programming in C++ by Bjarne Stroustrup

    Mathematics for Engineers by Anthony Croft

    Engineering Mechanics II by R.C. Hibbeler

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Khan Academy

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

Introduces advanced mechatronics systems and control concepts.

    Control Systems: Study of control theory, including feedback, stability, and system response.

    Mechanical Systems: Analysis and design of mechanical components and systems.

    Sensors and Actuators: Study of sensors, actuators, and their integration in mechatronic systems.

    Embedded Systems: Introduction to embedded systems design and programming.

    Mathematics III: Complex analysis and numerical methods for engineering applications.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Control Systems Engineering by Norman S. Nise

    Mechanical Systems Design by Anil K. Jain

    Sensors and Actuators by C. D. Johnson

    Embedded Systems Design by Peter Marwedel

    Advanced Engineering Mathematics by Erwin Kreyszig

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

Focuses on integrating mechatronic systems and advanced topics.

    Robotics: Study of robot design, control, and applications in various fields.

    Automated Systems: Analysis and design of automated systems for industrial applications.

    Signals and Systems: Study of signals, systems, and their analysis techniques.

    Mechatronic System Design: Principles and methods for designing integrated mechatronic systems.

    Project Work I: Practical project focusing on mechatronics design and implementation.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Robotics: Modelling, Planning, and Control by Bruno Siciliano

    Automated Systems by M. P. Groover

    Signals and Systems by Alan Oppenheim

    Mechatronic System Design by H. M. R. Rakapour

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

Continues with advanced topics and applications in mechatronics.

    Advanced Robotics: In-depth study of advanced robotics technologies and applications.

    Machine Vision: Techniques and systems for machine vision and image processing.

    Control Systems Design: Advanced methods for designing and implementing control systems.

    Elective I: Specialized elective course in a niche area of mechatronics.

    Project Work II: Extended project focusing on complex mechatronics systems and solutions.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Advanced Robotics by C. G. Atkeson

    Machine Vision by David D. R. N. Davis

    Control Systems Design by Gene Franklin

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: Khan Academy

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

Focuses on practical training and specialized topics.

    Embedded Systems Design: Advanced concepts in embedded systems for mechatronics applications.

    Industrial Automation: Study of automation technologies used in industrial settings.

    Elective II: Specialized elective course in a chosen area of mechatronics.

    Project Work III: Industry-oriented project to gain practical experience and skills.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Embedded Systems Design by Peter Marwedel

    Industrial Automation by Frank Lamb

YouTube Channels for Semester 6 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

Includes advanced projects and industry exposure.

    Research Project I: Research-based project on an advanced topic in mechatronics.

    Industry Internship: Practical experience gained through industry placement.

    Elective III: Specialized elective course in a niche area of mechatronics.

    Special Topics in Mechatronics: Study of contemporary issues and advancements in mechatronics.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Research Methods for Engineers by David W. S. Wang

    Industry Internship Guide by H. T. Riley

YouTube Channels for Semester 7 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Explained

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester focuses on major projects and preparing for industry entry.

    Major Project: Comprehensive project involving significant research and development in mechatronics.

    Industrial Internship II: Extended internship to deepen practical skills and industry understanding.

    Mechatronics Policy and Ethics: Study of regulations, policies, and ethical considerations in mechatronics.

    Elective IV: Advanced elective course in a specialized area of mechatronics.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Mechatronics: Principles and Applications by Godfrey C. Onwubolu

    Major Project Management by G. L. D. Nair

    Mechatronics Policy and Ethics by C. R. Scott

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Heroes

    Hindi: Unacademy

Future Paths

    Mechatronics Engineer: Design and develop integrated mechanical-electronic systems.

    Robotics Engineer: Work on designing and programming robots for various applications.

    Automation Engineer: Develop and implement automated systems in industrial processes.

    Embedded Systems Developer: Focus on designing and programming embedded systems for specific applications.

    Control Systems Engineer: Specialize in designing and managing control systems for automation and robotics.

Preparation Tips

    Strong Fundamentals: Build a solid foundation in core subjects such as mechanics, electronics, and programming.

    Hands-On Experience: Engage in practical projects and internships to gain real-world experience.

    Technical Skills: Develop proficiency in relevant software and tools used in mechatronics and automation.

    Stay Updated: Keep abreast of the latest advancements in mechatronics, robotics, and control systems.

    Participate in Competitions: Join engineering competitions, hackathons, and robotics challenges to apply your skills.

    Back

Nanotechnology Engineering

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester lays the groundwork in fundamental engineering concepts and science principles.

    Engineering Mechanics: Study of forces, motion, and energy applied to mechanical systems.

    Engineering Graphics: Development of technical drawing skills, including orthographic and isometric projections.

    Mathematics: Core mathematical concepts including calculus, algebra, and geometry applied in engineering.

    Physics: Fundamentals of physics including mechanics, thermodynamics, and electromagnetism.

    Chemistry: Introduction to chemistry with a focus on chemical reactions and material properties.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Mechanics by J.L. Meriam and L.G. Kraige

    Engineering Graphics by Frederick E. Giesecke

    Calculus by Michael Spivak

    Physics for Scientists and Engineers by Paul A. Tipler

    Chemistry: The Central Science by Theodore E. Brown

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: Crash Course

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

Focuses on core concepts in chemistry, electronics, and programming relevant to nanotechnology.

    Basic Electronics: Introduction to electronic components, circuits, and systems.

    Digital Systems: Study of digital logic, circuits, and systems used in electronic devices.

    Programming for Engineers: Basics of programming languages such as C++ and Python for engineering applications.

    Mathematics II: Advanced mathematical concepts including differential equations and linear algebra.

    Engineering Chemistry: Advanced study of chemical reactions, materials, and their properties.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Basic Electronics by B.L. Theraja

    Digital Systems by K. K. Aggarwal

    Programming in C++ by Bjarne Stroustrup

    Mathematics for Engineers by Anthony Croft

    Engineering Chemistry by Jain & Jain

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Khan Academy

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

Introduces core nanotechnology principles and techniques.

    Introduction to Nanotechnology: Basics of nanotechnology, including nanoscale materials and their properties.

    Material Science: Study of materials, including properties and applications in nanotechnology.

    Nano-fabrication Techniques: Techniques used to create nanoscale structures and devices.

    Mathematics III: Further mathematical techniques including complex analysis and numerical methods.

    Experimental Techniques in Nanotechnology: Laboratory techniques for investigating nanomaterials.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Introduction to Nanotechnology by Charles P. Poole Jr. and Frank J. Owens

    Materials Science and Engineering by William D. Callister

    Nanofabrication: Principles, Capabilities, and Limits by Peter N. P. L. Guo

    Numerical Methods for Engineers by Steven C. Chapra

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

Focuses on advanced nanotechnology applications and integration.

    Nano-optics: Study of optical properties and phenomena at the nanoscale.

    Quantum Mechanics: Basics of quantum theory and its applications in nanotechnology.

    Nano-biotechnology: Integration of nanotechnology with biological systems and processes.

    Elective I: Specialized elective course in a specific area of nanotechnology.

    Project Work I: Initial project focusing on practical applications of nanotechnology.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Nano-optics: Principles and Applications by Mark L. Brongersma

    Quantum Mechanics for Scientists and Engineers by David A. B.

    Nano-biotechnology: Progress and Prospects by Christopher A. R.

    English: MIT OpenCourseWare

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 5 Subjects:

Continues with advanced topics and practical training.

    Nanoelectronics: Study of electronic devices and circuits at the nanoscale.

    Advanced Nano-fabrication: Techniques and technologies for advanced nanofabrication.

    Elective II: Specialized elective course in a niche area of nanotechnology.

    Project Work II: Extended project focusing on advanced nanotechnology applications.

    Industry Internship: Practical experience gained through an industry placement.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Nanoelectronics: Physics, Engineering, and Applications by Karl Goser

    Advanced Nanofabrication by K. M. Kock

    English: Khan Academy

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 6 Subjects:

Focuses on specialized topics and research work.

    Nano-materials: Study of materials engineered at the nanoscale and their properties.

    Nano-sensors and Actuators: Design and applications of nanoscale sensors and actuators.

    Elective III: Advanced elective course in a specialized nanotechnology area.

    Research Project I: Research-based project on a topic within nanotechnology.

    Nanomaterials: Synthesis, Properties and Applications by A. S. Edelstein

    Nano-sensors and Actuators by S. P. Bhatia

    Hindi: NPTEL

Includes advanced research and practical industry exposure.

    Industry Internship II: Extended internship for deeper industry insight and experience.

    Elective IV: Specialized elective course in an emerging area of nanotechnology.

    Research Project II: Continuation of the research project with further development and analysis.

    Advanced Nanotechnology: Research and Applications by J. F. Gibbons

    Industry Internship Handbook by R. A. Johnson

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester focuses on major projects and industry readiness.

    Major Project: Comprehensive project involving significant research, development, and application of nanotechnology.

    Industrial Internship III: Extended internship to consolidate practical experience and industry skills.

    Nanotechnology Policy and Ethics: Study of regulatory, policy, and ethical considerations in nanotechnology.

    Elective V: Advanced elective course in a specialized or emerging area of nanotechnology.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Nanotechnology: Principles and Practices by D. V. Reddy

    Nanotechnology Policy and Ethics by H. E. Smith

    Major Project Management by G. L. D. Nair

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: Engineering Heroes

    Hindi: Unacademy

Future Paths

    Nanotechnologist: Work on the development and application of nanoscale materials and devices.

    Materials Scientist: Specialize in creating and analyzing new materials with nanoscale properties.

    Research Scientist: Conduct research in academic, governmental, or industrial settings focused on nanotechnology.

    Product Development Engineer: Design and develop products incorporating nanotechnology for various applications.

    Regulatory Specialist: Focus on policy, regulations, and safety standards related to nanotechnology.

Preparation Tips

    Strong Foundations: Build a solid understanding of core subjects such as physics, chemistry, and materials science.

    Hands-On Experience: Engage in laboratory work and practical projects to gain hands-on experience with nanotechnology.

    Technical Skills: Develop proficiency in nanotechnology-specific tools and techniques, including microscopy and fabrication methods.

    Stay Updated: Keep up with the latest research and developments in nanotechnology through journals, conferences, and online resources.

    Participate in Research: Involve yourself in research projects and internships to apply theoretical knowledge to real-world problems.

    Back

Energy Engineering

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester provides a foundation in core engineering principles and sciences.

    Engineering Mechanics: Study of forces, motion, and energy in mechanical systems.

    Engineering Graphics: Development of technical drawing skills, including orthographic and isometric projections.

    Mathematics: Core mathematical concepts including calculus, algebra, and geometry applied in engineering.

    Physics: Fundamentals of physics including mechanics, thermodynamics, and electromagnetism.

    Chemistry: Introduction to chemistry focusing on chemical reactions and properties.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Engineering Mechanics by J.L. Meriam and L.G. Kraige

    Engineering Graphics by Frederick E. Giesecke

    Calculus by Michael Spivak

    Physics for Scientists and Engineers by Paul A. Tipler

    Chemistry: The Central Science by Theodore E. Brown

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: Crash Course

    Hindi: Unacademy

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

Continues with core engineering subjects and introduces basic energy concepts.

    Thermodynamics: Study of energy, heat, and work in thermodynamic systems.

    Fluid Mechanics: Fundamentals of fluid behavior, including flow dynamics and properties.

    Mathematics II: Advanced mathematical concepts including differential equations and linear algebra.

    Engineering Materials: Study of materials and their properties in engineering applications.

    Electrical Circuits: Basics of electrical circuits, including analysis and design.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Fundamentals of Thermodynamics by Richard E. Sonntag

    Fluid Mechanics by Frank M. White

    Advanced Engineering Mathematics by Erwin Kreyszig

    Materials Science and Engineering by William D. Callister

    Electrical Engineering: Principles and Applications by Allan R. Hambley

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Khan Academy

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

Introduces specialized subjects in energy engineering and sustainability.

    Energy Conversion Systems: Study of various energy conversion processes and systems.

    Renewable Energy Technologies: Introduction to renewable energy sources such as solar, wind, and hydro power.

    Heat Transfer: Principles of heat transfer including conduction, convection, and radiation.

    Mathematics III: Further mathematical techniques including complex analysis and numerical methods.

    Environmental Engineering: Basics of environmental protection and management.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Energy Conversion by T. J. D. Lee

    Renewable Energy: Power for a Sustainable Future by Godfrey Boyle

    Heat Transfer by J.P. Holman

    Environmental Engineering by Howard S. Peavy

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    Hindi: NPTEL

Semester 4 Subjects:

Focuses on advanced topics in energy engineering and project work.

    Power Systems: Study of electrical power generation, transmission, and distribution systems.

    Energy Management: Techniques and strategies for efficient energy use and management.

    Elective I: Specialized elective course in a specific area of energy engineering.

    Project Work I: Initial project focusing on practical applications of energy engineering concepts.

    Power Systems Analysis by John J. Grainger

    Energy Management Handbook by Wayne C. Turner

    Energy Policy and Economics: Understanding of energy policies, economic aspects, and market dynamics.

    Elective II: Advanced elective course in an emerging field of energy engineering.

    Project Work II: Extended project focusing on complex energy engineering problems.

    Industry Internship: Practical experience gained through an industry placement.

    Advanced Energy Systems by D. E. Goldberg
