Recommended Reference Books:

    Quantum Mechanics: Concepts and Applications by Nouredine Zettili

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

This semester explores advanced quantum mechanics and applications.

    Quantum Dynamics: Study of time evolution and the quantum mechanical behavior of systems.

    Quantum Statistics: Introduction to Bose-Einstein and Fermi-Dirac statistics.

    Quantum Field Theory Basics: Overview of fields and particles in quantum mechanics.

    Lab IV: Advanced Quantum Experiments: Experiments in quantum mechanics.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Principles of Quantum Mechanics by R. Shankar

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

This semester focuses on quantum mechanics applications in various fields.

    Quantum Optics: Study the interaction of light and matter.

    Solid State Physics: Introduction to the physics of solids and materials.

    Quantum Information Theory: Explore the principles of information processing in quantum systems.

    Lab V: Quantum Optics Experiments: Hands-on experiments in quantum optics.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Quantum Optics: An Introduction by Mark Fox

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

This semester covers modern topics in quantum physics.

    Quantum Computing: Study the principles and applications of quantum computers.

    Nano-Physics: Understanding the quantum effects in nanomaterials.

    Advanced Topics in Quantum Mechanics: Study recent developments and research areas.

    Lab VI: Quantum Computing Simulations: Experiments in quantum computing.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Quantum Computation and Quantum Information by Michael A. Nielsen and Isaac L. Chuang

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

This semester emphasizes research and project work in quantum physics.

    Research Methods in Physics: Techniques for conducting research and data analysis.

    Project Work I: Independent research project under faculty supervision.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Research Methodology in Physics by Anirban Mukhopadhyay

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester focuses on project completion and presentation.

    Advanced Research Topics: Explore cutting-edge topics in quantum physics.

    Project Work II: Complete and present research projects.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Modern Quantum Mechanics by J. J. Sakurai

Future Career Paths

Studying Quantum Physics opens up diverse career opportunities:

    Quantum Physicist: Conduct research in quantum mechanics and related fields.

    Research Scientist: Work in research institutions focusing on quantum technologies.

    Quantum Computing Engineer: Develop and implement quantum algorithms and technologies.

    Optical Engineer: Design systems using quantum optics principles.

    Academician: Teach and conduct research in universities and colleges.

Preparation Tips

Here are some tips to excel in Quantum Physics:

    Solidify Mathematical Skills: Focus on mathematics, particularly linear algebra and calculus.

    Engage with Laboratory Work: Gain hands-on experience in quantum experiments.

    Study Key Concepts Thoroughly: Ensure a deep understanding of quantum principles and their applications.

    Follow Recent Developments: Stay updated with current research and advancements in quantum physics.

    Collaborate and Discuss: Participate in study groups to discuss complex topics.

Back

Bachelor of Arts (BA) Courses

  • World History
  • Philosophy of Art
  • Sociology
  • Psychology
  • Art History
  • Music Appreciation
  • Creative Writing
  • Media Studies
  • International Relations
  • Political Science

World History Course

Back

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces students to the ancient world and early civilizations.

    Introduction to World History: Overview of world history from the ancient period to the modern era.

    Ancient Civilizations: Study of major early civilizations like Mesopotamia, Egypt, Indus Valley, and China.

    Greek and Roman Empires: Exploration of the classical world and its influence on modern culture and governance.

    Early Asian Civilizations: Understanding the historical developments in China, Japan, and Southeast Asia.

    Research Methods in History: Introduction to historical research methodologies and source analysis.

Recommended Reference Books:

    A History of World Societies by John P. McKay

    The Histories by Herodotus

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: CrashCourse World History

    Hindi: Ancient History Hindi

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

This semester covers the medieval world and its socio-political developments.

    Medieval Europe: Examination of feudalism, the Church, and the Crusades in Europe.

    Islamic Civilization: Study of the rise and expansion of Islamic empires and their cultural achievements.

    Medieval Asia: Exploration of medieval dynasties in China, Japan, and Southeast Asia.

    Byzantine and Ottoman Empires: Understanding the political, cultural, and religious impact of these empires.

    History of Trade and Commerce: Analysis of early trade routes such as the Silk Road and their influence on societies.

Recommended Reference Books:

    The Middle Ages: A History by Johannes Fried

    The Silk Roads: A New History of the World by Peter Frankopan

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Medieval History Explained

    Hindi: Islamic Civilization Hindi

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

This semester focuses on the Renaissance, Reformation, and the Age of Discovery.

    European Renaissance: Study of the cultural, artistic, and intellectual revival in Europe.

    Reformation and Religious Wars: Analysis of the Protestant Reformation and its political consequences.

    Age of Discovery: Exploration of European exploration, colonization, and the impact on indigenous populations.

    History of Science and Technology: Examining major scientific discoveries and technological advancements.

    Colonialism and Its Impact: Understanding the effects of European colonialism on Africa, Asia, and the Americas.

Recommended Reference Books:

    The Renaissance by Will Durant

    A People's History of the United States by Howard Zinn

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: Renaissance History

    Hindi: Colonialism Explained Hindi

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

This semester covers the modern era, with emphasis on revolutions and the formation of nation-states.

    The Enlightenment: Study of intellectual movements in Europe that laid the groundwork for modern political thought.

    The French Revolution: In-depth analysis of the causes, course, and consequences of the French Revolution.

    Industrial Revolution: Examination of technological changes and their socio-economic impacts.

    Nationalism and Nation-State Formation: Understanding the rise of nationalism and its role in forming modern states.

    Latin American Independence Movements: Exploration of the independence movements in Latin America and their global significance.

Recommended Reference Books:

    The Age of Revolution by Eric Hobsbawm

    The Industrial Revolution by Patrick O’Brien

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: History of Revolutions

    Hindi: Enlightenment History Hindi

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

This semester focuses on the 19th and early 20th centuries, with emphasis on imperialism and global conflicts.

    Imperialism and Global Expansion: Examination of European imperialism and its impact on global politics and economies.

    World War I: Study of the causes, course, and consequences of World War I.

    Russian Revolution: Understanding the Russian Revolution and its impact on global ideologies.

    The Interwar Period: Exploration of the global political and economic landscape between World War I and World War II.

    Women's Rights Movements: Study of the early women's rights movements and their impact on global society.

Recommended Reference Books:

    The Scramble for Africa by Thomas Pakenham

    The Russian Revolution by Richard Pipes

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: World War I Explained

    Hindi: Russian Revolution Hindi

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

This semester covers the events leading up to, during, and after World War II.

    World War II: Study of the causes, major events, and consequences of World War II.

    The Holocaust: Examination of the Holocaust and its impact on world history and human rights.

    The Cold War: Understanding the ideological, political, and military conflicts between the USA and USSR.

    Decolonization: Exploration of post-World War II decolonization movements across Africa and Asia.

    United Nations and Global Governance: Study of the formation and role of the United Nations in maintaining international peace.

Recommended Reference Books:

    The Second World War by Antony Beevor

    The Cold War: A New History by John Lewis Gaddis

YouTube Channels for Semester 6 Subjects:

    English: Cold War History

    Hindi: World War II Hindi

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

This semester focuses on contemporary history and global developments in the late 20th century.

    The End of the Cold War: Study of the factors leading to the collapse of the Soviet Union and the end of the Cold War.

    Globalization and Its Impact: Analysis of the rise of globalization and its economic, political, and cultural consequences.

    Technological Advancements in the Modern World: Exploration of major technological advancements and their impact on society.

    Environmental Movements: Study of global environmental movements and their impact on policy and society.

    Post-Colonialism: Understanding the political, social, and economic developments in post-colonial societies.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Globalization: A Very Short Introduction by Manfred B. Steger

    The Post-Colonial Studies Reader by Bill Ashcroft

YouTube Channels for Semester 7 Subjects:

    English: Modern World History

    Hindi: Environmental Movements Hindi

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester integrates historical knowledge with career preparation and future developments.

    Capstone Project in World History: A comprehensive project showcasing students’ skills and understanding of world history.

    Future of Global Governance: Exploration of potential developments in global political and economic systems.

    History of Human Rights: Study of the evolution of human rights from ancient to modern times.

    History of Global Conflict Resolution: Understanding the history and methods of resolving conflicts between nations.

    Ethics in Historical Research: Examining the ethical considerations in studying and interpreting historical events.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Human Rights: A Very Short Introduction by Andrew Clapham

    Global Governance and the Emergence of Global Institutions for the 21st Century by Augusto Lopez-Claros

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: Capstone in World History

    Hindi: Global Governance Hindi

Future Career Paths

Studying World History opens up diverse career opportunities:

    Historian: Researching and analyzing historical events and trends.

    Archivist: Preserving and cataloging historical documents and artifacts.

    Museum Curator: Managing collections and exhibits in museums.

    History Teacher/Professor: Teaching history at the school or university level.

    Journalist: Reporting on historical events, trends, and their relevance to current issues.

    Policy Analyst: Providing insights on historical trends to shape future policies.

Preparation Tips

Here are some tips to excel in World History:

    Stay Curious: Develop a genuine interest in understanding diverse historical periods and cultures.

    Read Extensively: Go beyond the syllabus and read widely to gain deeper insights into historical events.

    Practice Source Analysis: Get accustomed to evaluating primary and secondary historical sources critically.

    Engage in Discussions: Participate in debates and discussions on historical topics.

    Develop Writing Skills: Strengthen your ability to write clearly and analytically about historical events.

    Back

Philosophy of Art Course

Back

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces students to foundational concepts and historical perspectives in the philosophy of art.

    Introduction to Aesthetics: Overview of aesthetic theory, exploring questions like "What is art?" and "What makes something beautiful?"

    Art and Perception: Study of how humans perceive art and the sensory experience of beauty.

    Classical Theories of Art: Examination of key philosophical ideas on art from ancient philosophers like Plato and Aristotle.

    Art and Emotion: Exploration of how art evokes emotions and the relationship between art and human feeling.

    Art Criticism: Introduction to different methods of critiquing art, including formalism and contextual analysis.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Aesthetics: A Comprehensive Anthology by Steven M. Cahn and Aaron Meskin

    The Birth of Tragedy by Friedrich Nietzsche

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: CrashCourse Philosophy

    Hindi: Art and Aesthetics in Hindi

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

This semester covers modern theories of art and introduces students to the concept of representation and symbolism in art.

    Modern Aesthetic Theories: Study of key modern thinkers such as Kant, Hegel, and Schopenhauer on beauty and the sublime.

    Representation in Art: Exploration of how art represents reality and the philosophical issues related to mimesis and abstraction.

    Symbolism in Art: Understanding the use of symbols in art and how they convey deeper meanings.

    Expression and Intent in Art: Analysis of the relationship between an artist’s intent and the interpretation of their work.

    Art and Society: Examination of the societal role of art and its impact on culture and politics.

Recommended Reference Books:

    The Critique of Judgment by Immanuel Kant

    Art and Its Objects by Richard Wollheim

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Modern Philosophy of Art

    Hindi: Symbolism in Art Hindi

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

This semester focuses on the intersections of art, ethics, and politics, and further explores the nature of creativity.

    Art and Morality: Discussion of whether art has a moral dimension, and how ethical considerations impact artistic creation.

    Political Philosophy of Art: Examination of art’s role in political movements and its ability to challenge or reinforce power structures.

    The Philosophy of Creativity: Study of what it means to create, and the sources and nature of artistic creativity.

    Art and Propaganda: Analysis of how art has been used as a tool for propaganda in various political regimes.

    Art in the Public Sphere: Understanding the relationship between public art, its accessibility, and its role in the common good.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Philosophy of Art: A Contemporary Introduction by Noël Carroll

    Art and Morality by José Luis Bermúdez

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: Art and Ethics

    Hindi: Political Philosophy of Art in Hindi

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

This semester delves into 20th-century art movements and explores contemporary debates in aesthetics.

    20th-Century Avant-Garde Movements: Study of radical art movements like Dadaism, Surrealism, and Expressionism.

    Postmodernism and Art: Examination of postmodern critiques of traditional art and the rise of conceptual art.

    The Aesthetics of Everyday Life: Exploration of how aesthetics apply not just to fine art, but to everyday objects and experiences.

    Art and Technology: Analysis of the intersection of art and technology, including digital art, photography, and film.

    Contemporary Aesthetic Debates: Discussion of current philosophical debates surrounding the nature of art and aesthetic value.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Theories of Modern Art by Herschel B. Chipp

    Postmodernism: A Very Short Introduction by Christopher Butler

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: 20th Century Avant-Garde Art

    Hindi: Contemporary Aesthetic Debates in Hindi

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

This semester explores the relationship between art, culture, and identity, and introduces post-colonial perspectives on art.

    Art and Cultural Identity: Study of how art reflects and shapes cultural identities and social norms.

    Feminist Aesthetics: Examination of feminist critiques of traditional aesthetics and the role of women in art history.

    Post-Colonial Aesthetics: Exploration of how colonialism and post-colonialism have influenced global art forms and interpretations.

    Art and Race: Understanding the relationship between race, representation, and art in different historical and social contexts.

    Queer Theory and Art: Analysis of how queer theory has influenced contemporary interpretations of art and representation.

Recommended Reference Books:

    The Postcolonial Exotic by Graham Huggan

    Feminist Aesthetics by Hilde Hein

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: Feminist Art Theory

    Hindi: Post-Colonial Art Hindi

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

This semester focuses on global art movements and how they intersect with contemporary social issues.

    Globalization and Art: Study of how global economic and cultural exchange has influenced contemporary art practices.

    Art and Environmentalism: Exploration of the relationship between art and ecological concerns, focusing on eco-art and sustainability.

    Digital Aesthetics: Analysis of how digital technology has reshaped the creation, distribution, and experience of art.

    Art and Human Rights: Study of how art has been used as a tool to promote human rights and social justice.

    Public Art and Activism: Examination of the role of public art in social movements and political activism.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Globalization and Contemporary Art by Jonathan Harris

    Eco-Art Therapy by Amanda Alders Pike

YouTube Channels for Semester 6 Subjects:

    English: Global Contemporary Art

    Hindi: Digital Aesthetics in Hindi

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

This semester deals with philosophical theories on the interpretation and meaning of art in a globalized world.

    Theories of Art Interpretation: Study of different philosophical approaches to interpreting art, including hermeneutics and semiotics.

    Art and the Global South: Exploration of how art from the Global South challenges Western-centric aesthetic norms.

    Philosophy of Installation Art: Understanding the unique challenges and interpretations of installation art.

    Performance Art and Aesthetics: Study of how performance art challenges traditional notions of art and the role of the artist.

    Cross-Cultural Art Forms: Exploration of how art forms from different cultures interact, influence each other, and create new meanings.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Theory of Interpretation by Hans-Georg Gadamer

    Performance Art: From Futurism to the Present by RoseLee Goldberg

YouTube Channels for Semester 7 Subjects:

    English: Global Art Interpretation

    Hindi: Art and Global South in Hindi

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester focuses on integrating philosophy with artistic practice and prepares students for their capstone projects.

    Philosophy of Art Capstone Project: Students will undertake a comprehensive project that showcases their understanding of art and aesthetics, along with philosophical analysis.

    Philosophy of Art in the 21st Century: Exploration of contemporary challenges and opportunities in art and philosophy, including the rise of AI and virtual art forms.

    Art and Ethics in Practice: Examination of the ethical responsibilities of artists, curators, and critics in the modern art world.

    Art and Global Crises: Study of how contemporary art responds to global crises such as pandemics, wars, and climate change.

    Future of Art and Aesthetics: Speculation on future trends in art and aesthetics in an increasingly interconnected world.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Art and the Future by Maurice Tuchman

    Philosophy and Art: The Development of Art in the Age of AI by Daniel Cohen

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: Art in the 21st Century

    Hindi: Art and Ethics in Hindi

Future Career Paths

Studying the Philosophy of Art opens diverse career opportunities:

    Art Critic: Analyzing and critiquing art from philosophical and aesthetic perspectives.

    Museum Curator: Managing and interpreting art collections in museums and galleries.

    Art Educator: Teaching art history, aesthetics, and philosophy at schools or universities.

    Gallery Director: Overseeing the operations and exhibitions of an art gallery.

    Art Writer: Writing books, essays, and articles on art and its philosophical implications.

    Art Consultant: Advising collectors, galleries, or corporations on art acquisitions and exhibitions.

Preparation Tips

Here are some tips to excel in Philosophy of Art:

    Engage with Artworks: Visit galleries, museums, and exhibitions to experience art firsthand.

    Stay Critical: Analyze artworks with a philosophical mindset, questioning assumptions about beauty and value.

    Read Widely: Explore both primary philosophical texts and contemporary art criticism.

    Join Discussions: Participate in class discussions, art forums, and online communities focused on art and aesthetics.

    Practice Writing: Develop your ability to write thoughtful, critical analyses of art and philosophical theories.

    Back

Sociology Course

Back

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces students to the fundamentals of sociology and its key concepts.

    Introduction to Sociology: Overview of sociology, its scope, and significance in understanding society.

    Research Methods in Sociology: Introduction to qualitative and quantitative research methods used in sociological studies.

    Social Institutions: Examination of major social institutions such as family, education, religion, and economy.

    Cultural Sociology: Exploration of culture, its components, and its impact on social behavior.

    Social Stratification: Study of social hierarchies, class structures, and inequality in society.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Sociology: A Global Perspective by Joan Ferrante

    Introduction to Sociology by Anthony Giddens

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: Crash Course Sociology

    Hindi: Sociology in Hindi

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

This semester delves deeper into social behavior and interaction.

    Socialization: Study of the process of socialization and its role in personality development.

    Group Dynamics: Examination of social groups, their structures, and the impact of group behavior.

    Deviance and Social Control: Analysis of social norms, deviant behavior, and mechanisms of social control.

    Gender and Society: Exploration of gender roles, identity, and the social construction of gender.

    Race and Ethnicity: Examination of the social dynamics of race, ethnicity, and their impact on society.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Deviant Behavior by Erich Goode

    Gender Trouble by Judith Butler

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Socialization in Society

    Hindi: Gender Studies in Hindi

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

This semester focuses on social change, movements, and the implications of globalization.

    Social Change and Development: Examination of theories of social change and their implications for development.

    Social Movements: Study of the nature, types, and impacts of social movements throughout history.

    Globalization and Society: Analysis of the effects of globalization on social structures and cultures.

    Urban Sociology: Exploration of urban life, issues, and the sociological implications of urbanization.

    Environmental Sociology: Study of the relationship between society and the environment, including sustainability.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Social Change by Charles W. Short

    Globalization: A Very Short Introduction by Manfred B. Steger

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: Globalization Studies

    Hindi: Urban Sociology in Hindi

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

This semester explores advanced topics in sociology, including the interplay of social structures and agency.

    Social Theory: Study of key sociological theories, including functionalism, conflict theory, and symbolic interactionism.

    Sociology of Education: Exploration of the role of education in society and its impact on social stratification.

    Family and Kinship: Examination of family structures, roles, and the sociological implications of kinship.

    Political Sociology: Analysis of the relationship between society and politics, including power dynamics.

    Health and Society: Study of social determinants of health, healthcare systems, and health disparities.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Social Theory: A Very Short Introduction by Robert S. Adams

    The Sociology of Health and Illness by Peter Conrad

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: Sociology of Education

    Hindi: Political Sociology in Hindi

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

This semester focuses on sociology in the context of modern societal issues and challenges.

    Social Problems: Examination of contemporary social issues such as poverty, crime, and discrimination.

    Media and Society: Study of the role of media in shaping public perception and social norms.

    Work and Occupations: Analysis of the sociology of work, labor markets, and occupational roles.

    Social Policy: Exploration of the formulation and impact of social policies on various communities.

    International Sociology: Study of sociological perspectives on global issues and cross-cultural interactions.

Recommended Reference Books:

    The Social Problems by D. Stanley Eitzen

    Media and Society: An Introduction by C. Richard S. Parker

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: Social Problems and Solutions

    Hindi: International Sociology in Hindi

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

This semester explores various sociological approaches to understanding human behavior and social phenomena.

    Quantitative Sociology: Introduction to statistical methods and their application in sociological research.

    Qualitative Sociology: Exploration of qualitative research methods, including interviews and ethnography.

    Social Change Theories: Examination of theories explaining the mechanisms of social change.

    Critical Sociology: Study of the critical perspectives in sociology and their implications for social justice.

    Comparative Sociology: Exploration of sociological comparisons across cultures and societies.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Research Methods in Sociology by William J. Goode

    Critical Sociology: An Introduction by David L. Swanson

YouTube Channels for Semester 6 Subjects:

    English: Quantitative Methods in Sociology

    Hindi: Critical Sociology in Hindi

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

This semester focuses on specialized areas of sociology and contemporary debates.

    Sociology of Emotions: Study of how emotions are socially constructed and their impact on social interactions.

    Sociology of Religion: Exploration of the role of religion in society and its social implications.

    Sociology of Aging: Examination of aging as a social phenomenon and its impact on individuals and society.

    Sociology of Migration: Study of migration patterns and their implications for social structures.

    Sociology of Globalization: Analysis of the social dimensions of globalization and its impact on cultures.

Recommended Reference Books:

    The Sociology of Emotions by David L. Altheide

    Religion in Society: A Sociology of Religion by N.J. Demerath

YouTube Channels for Semester 7 Subjects:

    English: Sociology of Religion

    Hindi: Sociology of Migration in Hindi

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester focuses on integrating sociological concepts and applying them to real-world issues.

    Capstone Project: Students will undertake a comprehensive project that showcases their understanding of sociology through empirical research or applied projects.

    Sociology and Public Policy: Study of the relationship between sociological research and public policy formulation.

    Advanced Topics in Sociology: Exploration of current trends and debates in the field of sociology.

    Internship or Fieldwork: Practical experience in a sociological setting, allowing students to apply their knowledge in real-world contexts.

    Thesis Writing: Preparation of a thesis that integrates theory and practice in sociology.

Recommended Reference Books:

    The Craft of Research by Wayne C. Booth

    Public Policy and Sociology by John R. Green

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: Sociology Capstone Projects

    Hindi: Public Policy in Hindi

Future Career Paths

Studying Sociology opens diverse career opportunities:

    Social Researcher: Conducting research to understand social patterns and trends.

    Policy Analyst: Analyzing and developing public policies to address social issues.

    Community Organizer: Working with communities to promote social change and advocacy.

    Social Worker: Providing support and services to individuals and families in need.

    Educator: Teaching sociology at various educational institutions.

    Market Research Analyst: Analyzing consumer behavior and market trends.

Preparation Tips

Here are some tips to excel in Sociology:

    Stay Informed: Keep up with current events and social issues to understand their sociological implications.

    Engage in Discussions: Participate in debates and discussions on sociological topics to enhance critical thinking.

    Conduct Field Research: Gain practical experience through fieldwork or internships to apply theoretical knowledge.

    Read Widely: Explore both classical and contemporary sociological literature.

    Network with Professionals: Connect with sociologists and professionals in related fields to expand your opportunities.

    Back

Psychology

Back

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the foundational concepts and theories in psychology.

    Introduction to Psychology: Overview of key concepts, theories, and research in psychology.

    Biological Bases of Behavior: Explore the role of the brain, nervous system, and genetics in behavior.

    Developmental Psychology: Study of human growth and development across the lifespan.

    Psychology of Learning: Examination of classical and operant conditioning, and observational learning.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Psychology by David G. Myers

    Developmental Psychology by Elizabeth B. Hurlock

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

This semester focuses on personality, emotions, and social psychology.

    Personality Psychology: Study of various theories of personality and personality assessment techniques.

    Emotion and Motivation: Explore the psychological theories behind emotions and motivation.

    Social Psychology: Study how individual behavior is influenced by the social environment.

    Research Methods in Psychology: Introduction to research design, sampling methods, and data analysis in psychological research.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Theories of Personality by Calvin S. Hall

    Social Psychology by Robert A. Baron

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

This semester delves into abnormal psychology, cognition, and memory.

    Cognitive Psychology: Study of mental processes including perception, memory, and problem-solving.

    Abnormal Psychology: Exploration of psychological disorders, their symptoms, and treatments.

    Memory and Learning: Understanding the processes involved in learning and memory storage/retrieval.

    Psychological Testing: Introduction to the principles of psychological testing and assessment.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Cognitive Psychology by Robert L. Solso

    Abnormal Psychology by Ronald J. Comer

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

This semester covers health psychology, clinical psychology, and neuropsychology.

    Health Psychology: Explore how psychological factors affect health and well-being.

    Clinical Psychology: Study the application of psychological theory and methods in treating mental health issues.

    Neuropsychology: Study the relationship between brain function and behavior.

    Ethics in Psychology: Understand the ethical principles guiding psychological research and practice.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Health Psychology by Shelley E. Taylor

    Principles of Neuropsychology by Eric A. Zillmer

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

This semester focuses on industrial-organizational psychology, forensic psychology, and therapeutic techniques.

    Industrial-Organizational Psychology: Study psychological principles in the workplace, including motivation, leadership, and job satisfaction.

    Forensic Psychology: Explore the application of psychology in legal and criminal justice settings.

    Therapeutic Techniques: Introduction to various therapeutic techniques used in clinical practice, such as CBT and psychodynamic therapy.

    Statistics in Psychology: Learn about statistical methods for analyzing psychological data.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Industrial/Organizational Psychology by Paul E. Spector

    Forensic Psychology by Matthew T. Huss

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

This semester focuses on cross-cultural psychology, environmental psychology, and psychological assessment.

    Cross-Cultural Psychology: Study how culture influences psychological processes and behavior.

    Environmental Psychology: Explore how physical environments affect behavior and well-being.

    Psychological Assessment: Study advanced techniques for assessing mental health and cognitive abilities.

    Child Psychology: Examination of psychological development and challenges in children.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Cross-Cultural Psychology by John W. Berry

    Environmental Psychology: Principles and Practice by Robert Gifford

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

This semester covers counseling psychology, psychopathology, and independent research.

    Counseling Psychology: Explore the practice of counseling, focusing on different therapeutic approaches.

    Psychopathology: Study the origins, symptoms, and treatments of various psychological disorders.

    Independent Research in Psychology: Conduct independent research on a selected topic under supervision.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Counseling Psychology by Charles J. Gelso

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester focuses on clinical internship, case studies, and advanced psychological research.

    Clinical Internship: Gain hands-on experience by working with clinical psychologists in a healthcare setting.

    Case Studies in Psychology: Analyze real-life case studies to apply psychological theories and methods.

    Advanced Research Methods: Learn advanced research techniques, focusing on experimental design and data interpretation.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Case Studies in Clinical Psychology by Frank W. Putnam

Future Career Paths

Studying Psychology opens up diverse career opportunities:

    Clinical Psychologist: Diagnose and treat mental health issues through therapy and counseling.

    Forensic Psychologist: Apply psychological principles in legal and criminal justice contexts.

    Industrial-Organizational Psychologist: Improve employee performance and well-being in the workplace.

    Counselor: Provide mental health support and therapy to individuals facing emotional and psychological challenges.

    Research Psychologist: Conduct psychological research in various subfields such as cognition, behavior, and emotions.

Preparation Tips

Here are some tips to excel in Psychology:

    Engage in Internships: Gain practical experience through internships in clinical or research settings.

    Stay Informed: Keep up with the latest psychological research and breakthroughs by reading journals and articles.

    Practice Self-Care: Psychology is a demanding field; prioritize your mental health while studying and working in the field.

    Participate in Research: Engage in research projects to deepen your understanding of psychological theories and methodologies.

Back

B.A. in Art History

Back

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces foundational concepts in art history and visual analysis.

    Introduction to Art History: Overview of the major periods and movements in art history.

    Visual Literacy: Develop skills to critically analyze visual images and artworks.

    Western Art I: Ancient to Medieval: Study the art of ancient civilizations through the medieval period.

    Art and Society: Exploration of the social, cultural, and political contexts of art.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Gardner's Art Through the Ages by Fred S. Kleiner

    The Story of Art by E.H. Gombrich

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

This semester builds on the knowledge of art movements and cultural influence.

    Renaissance Art: Study the art and cultural developments during the Renaissance.

    Non-Western Art I: Introduction to the art and architecture of Asia, Africa, and the Americas.

    Art Criticism and Theory: Learn how to critique and interpret art using different theoretical frameworks.

    Art History Methodologies: Explore different methodologies used in the study of art history.

Recommended Reference Books:

    The Lives of the Artists by Giorgio Vasari

    Ways of Seeing by John Berger

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

This semester focuses on modern and contemporary art.

    Baroque and Rococo Art: Study of the dramatic art of the Baroque and Rococo periods.

    Modern Art I: Impressionism to Cubism: Exploration of modern art movements from the late 19th to early 20th centuries.

    Non-Western Art II: Continuation of the study of art from non-Western cultures.

    Art Conservation and Restoration: Learn the techniques of preserving and restoring artworks.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Art in Theory, 1900-2000 by Charles Harrison

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

This semester delves into the study of postmodernism and contemporary art movements.

    Modern Art II: Dada to Abstract Expressionism: Study of art movements from the early 20th century to the mid-century.

    Art and Architecture of India: Exploration of the artistic and architectural traditions of India.

    Postmodernism in Art: Examine postmodern theories and their impact on contemporary art.

    Art and Politics: Study how political events and ideologies influence art.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Postmodernism: A Very Short Introduction by Christopher Butler

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

This semester focuses on advanced art history topics and research methods.

    Contemporary Art: Study of art movements from the 1960s to the present day.

    Feminism and Art: Exploration of the role of gender and feminist theories in art history.

    Curatorial Studies: Learn the theory and practice of curating exhibitions and collections.

    Research Methods in Art History: Study the methodologies and tools used in art history research.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Theories of Modern Art by Herschel B. Chipp

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

This semester focuses on independent study and analysis of artworks.

    Independent Study in Art History: Engage in self-directed research on a chosen topic in art history.

    Art, Culture, and Technology: Explore the intersection of art, culture, and emerging technologies.

    Museum Studies: Study the role of museums in the preservation and presentation of art.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Museum Studies: An Anthology of Contexts by Bettina Messias Carbonell

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

This semester is dedicated to research, writing, and exhibition design.

    Research Project I: Start working on a thesis or research paper in art history.

    Exhibition Design: Learn the principles of designing and organizing art exhibitions.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Exhibition Design by David Dernie

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester focuses on the completion and presentation of a major research project.

    Research Project II: Complete and present the research project or thesis.

    Professional Practices in Art History: Study the professional practices in art curation, writing, and research.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Researching Visual Arts Education in Museums and Galleries by Maria Xanthoudaki

Future Career Paths

Studying Art History opens up diverse career opportunities:

    Art Historian: Conduct research and analysis of art history topics.

    Curator: Work in museums and galleries to organize and manage art collections and exhibitions.

    Art Critic: Write and publish critical essays on art and artists.

    Gallery Manager: Manage the day-to-day operations of art galleries.

    Art Appraiser: Determine the value of artworks for museums, galleries, or private collectors.

Preparation Tips

Here are some tips to excel in Art History:

    Develop Visual Analysis Skills: Practice analyzing and interpreting artworks in detail.

    Read Widely: Engage with art history books, journals, and articles to deepen your understanding of the field.

    Visit Museums and Galleries: Regularly visit museums and galleries to see artworks in person and learn from exhibitions.

    Research and Write: Develop strong research and writing skills by engaging with primary sources and writing about art.

    Stay Current: Keep up with current trends in art and art history to stay informed about new developments.

Back

Music Appreciation Course

Back

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the fundamentals of music appreciation.

    Introduction to Music: Explore the basic elements of music, including rhythm, melody, harmony, and texture.

    History of Music: Overview of music history from ancient to contemporary times.

    Music Notation and Theory: Basics of reading music and understanding musical notation.

    Genres of Music: Introduction to various music genres, including classical, jazz, rock, and world music.

    Listening Skills: Developing critical listening skills to analyze and appreciate music.

Recommended Reference Books:

    The Complete Musician: An Integrated Approach to Tonal Theory, Analysis, and Listening by Steven G. Laitz

    Music: An Appreciation by Roger Kamien

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: Music Appreciation

    Hindi: Music Notation Hindi

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

This semester dives deeper into different styles and cultural contexts of music.

    Western Classical Music: Study the evolution of Western classical music from the Renaissance to the present.

    Music and Culture: Explore the relationship between music and cultural identity.

    Folk and Traditional Music: Understand the significance of folk and traditional music in various cultures.

    Music in Film and Media: Analyze the role of music in film, television, and multimedia.

    Contemporary Music Trends: Discuss current trends and movements in the music industry.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Worlds of Music: An Introduction to the Music of the World's Peoples by Jeff Todd Titon

    Listening to Music by Craig Wright

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Western Classical Music

    Hindi: Folk Music Hindi

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

This semester focuses on specific genres and their historical contexts.

    Jazz and Blues: Explore the origins and evolution of jazz and blues music.

    Rock and Pop Music: Analyze the impact of rock and pop music on society and culture.

    World Music: Study the diverse musical traditions from around the globe.

    Music and Technology: Investigate how technology has influenced music production and consumption.

    Women in Music: Examine the contributions of women in various musical genres.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Jazz: A History of America's Music by Geoffrey C. Ward

    Popular Music in America: The Beat Goes On by Michael Campbell

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: Jazz and Blues

    Hindi: Women in Music Hindi

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

This semester emphasizes music analysis and composition.

    Music Analysis: Techniques for analyzing musical compositions across genres.

    Introduction to Music Composition: Basics of composing music, including melody and harmony.

    Lyric Writing: Explore the art of writing lyrics and their significance in music.

    Music and Emotion: Study the psychological impact of music on emotions and behavior.

    Music Criticism: Learn how to write reviews and critiques of musical performances and compositions.

Recommended Reference Books:

    How to Write Songs on Guitar by Rikky Rooksby

    The Complete Singer-Songwriter by Jeffrey Pepper Rodgers

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: Music Composition

    Hindi: Lyric Writing Hindi

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

This semester focuses on practical applications and performance.

    Music Performance: Opportunities for students to perform music in various styles.

    Conducting and Ensemble Skills: Basics of conducting and leading musical ensembles.

    Music and Society: Explore the social and cultural roles of music in different societies.

    Music and Politics: Analyze how music influences and reflects political movements.

    Community Engagement through Music: Understand the role of music in community building and social change.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Performing Music: A Handbook for Music Teachers by Scott E. W. Wright

    The Music Teacher's Handbook by Richard E. T. Turner

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: Music Performance

    Hindi: Music and Society Hindi

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

This semester focuses on global music traditions and their influences.

    Non-Western Music Traditions: Explore music traditions from Africa, Asia, and Latin America.

    Music in Religious Practices: Study the role of music in various religious contexts.

    Comparative Musicology: Analyze and compare music from different cultures.

    Music in the Digital Age: Investigate how digital technology shapes music production and consumption.

    Documenting Music Traditions: Explore methods for documenting and preserving music traditions.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Ethnomusicology: A Contemporary Reader by Henry Stobart

    The Study of Ethnomusicology: Thirty-One Issues and Concepts by Bruno Nettl

YouTube Channels for Semester 6 Subjects:

    English: Non-Western Music

    Hindi: Music Documentation Hindi

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

This semester emphasizes research and presentation in music appreciation.

    Research Methods in Music: Introduction to research methodologies specific to music studies.

    Music Presentation Skills: Developing skills for presenting musical topics effectively.

    Critical Listening Projects: Engage in projects that involve critical listening and analysis.

    Music and Technology Workshop: Hands-on experience with music technology and software.

    Music Education Advocacy: Explore strategies for advocating music education in schools and communities.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Researching Music: A Guide for Students by Philip W. McKinney

    Presenting Music: A Guide for Students by David E. Day

YouTube Channels for Semester 7 Subjects:

    English: Music Research

    Hindi: Music Education Hindi

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester focuses on capstone projects and career preparation.

    Capstone Project: A comprehensive project showcasing knowledge and skills acquired throughout the course.

    Final Portfolio Presentation: Students present a portfolio of their work in music appreciation.

    Career Paths in Music: Explore various career opportunities in the music industry.

    Networking in the Music Industry: Strategies for building professional connections in the music field.

    Reflective Practice: Reflect on personal growth and learning throughout the program.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Creating a Successful Career in Music by Eric M. Lindstrom

    The Complete Guide to Music Business Success by Philip A. Meisner

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: Capstone Project in Music

    Hindi: Music Career Hindi

Future Career Paths

Studying Music Appreciation opens up diverse career opportunities:

    Music Educator: Teach music appreciation in schools or community programs.

    Music Critic: Write reviews and critiques for music publications or websites.

    Music Event Coordinator: Plan and coordinate music events and festivals.

    Music Researcher: Conduct research in musicology and ethnomusicology.

    Music Producer: Work in music production and recording.

Preparation Tips

Here are some tips to excel in Music Appreciation:

    Listen Actively: Engage with music actively by analyzing its elements and context.

    Attend Live Performances: Experience music live to gain a deeper appreciation of the art form.

    Participate in Discussions: Engage in discussions about music with peers to broaden your perspective.

    Explore Different Genres: Diversify your listening habits by exploring various musical genres.

    Stay Informed: Follow music news and developments in the industry.

    Back

Creative Writing Course

Back

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the fundamentals of creative writing.

    Introduction to Creative Writing: Overview of creative writing forms and techniques.

    Writing Fundamentals: Basics of grammar, punctuation, and style.

    Reading as a Writer: Analyze various texts to understand different writing styles.

    Short Fiction: Introduction to writing short stories, focusing on narrative structure.

    Poetry Basics: Explore forms, techniques, and elements of poetry.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Writing Down the Bones: Freeing the Writer Within by Natalie Goldberg

    The Creative Writing Coursebook: Forty Authors Share Advice and Exercises from Their Own Writing Courses by Julia Bell and Paul Magrs

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: Creative Writing

    Hindi: Poetry Hindi

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

This semester delves deeper into various forms of creative writing.

    Character Development: Techniques for creating believable and compelling characters.

    Dialogue Writing: Focus on crafting authentic and engaging dialogue.

    Flash Fiction: Explore the art of writing very short stories.

    Writing for Young Adults: Study the characteristics of YA literature.

    Introduction to Creative Nonfiction: Explore techniques in memoirs, essays, and literary journalism.

Recommended Reference Books:

    The Art of Fiction: Notes on Craft for Young Writers by John Gardner

    Bird by Bird: Some Instructions on Writing and Life by Anne Lamott

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Character Development

    Hindi: Dialogue Writing Hindi

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

This semester focuses on poetry and advanced writing techniques.

    Advanced Poetry Writing: Experiment with various poetic forms and styles.

    Writing Workshop: Peer critique sessions to enhance writing skills.

    Genre Fiction: Explore the characteristics of genres like fantasy, sci-fi, and mystery.

    Creative Writing and Technology: Discuss the impact of technology on writing and publishing.

    Writing for Performance: Techniques for writing scripts for theater and screen.

Recommended Reference Books:

    The Poet’s Companion: A Guide to the Pleasures of Writing Poetry by Kim Addonizio and Dorianne Laux

    Writing for the Screen: A Practical Guide by Craig Batty

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: Poetry Writing

    Hindi: Creative Writing Tech Hindi

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

This semester emphasizes writing techniques and publishing.

    Writing Techniques: Advanced techniques for storytelling and narrative development.

    Publishing and Marketing: Understand the publishing process and how to market your work.

    Editing and Revision: Strategies for editing and revising creative work.

    Writing for Digital Media: Explore writing for blogs, social media, and online platforms.

    Understanding Copyright and Ethics: Basics of copyright laws and ethical considerations in writing.

Recommended Reference Books:

    On Writing: A Memoir of the Craft by Stephen King

    Writing Down the Bones: Freeing the Writer Within by Natalie Goldberg

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: Editing and Revision

    Hindi: Digital Media Writing Hindi

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

This semester focuses on specialized writing forms and projects.

    Playwriting: Explore the craft of writing for theater.

    Screenwriting: Introduction to writing scripts for film and television.

    Writing for Children and Young Adults: Techniques specific to children's literature.

    Creative Writing Projects: Engage in longer-form creative writing projects.

    Writing and Identity: Explore how personal identity influences writing.

Recommended Reference Books:

    The Complete Handbook of Novel Writing by Tom McGinty

    Writing the Breakout Novel by Donald Maass

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: Playwriting

    Hindi: Writing for Children Hindi

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

This semester focuses on the business of writing and creative careers.

    Creative Writing Business: Explore the business side of being a writer, including contracts and negotiations.

    Networking and Building a Writing Community: Techniques for building relationships in the writing world.

    Advanced Fiction Writing: Work on advanced narrative techniques and story arcs.

    Writing Workshops: Participate in peer workshops to refine your work.

    Literary Journals and Magazines: Understand the role of literary journals in publishing.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Writing Fiction: A Guide to Narrative Craft by Janet Burroway

    Steering the Craft: A Twenty-First-Century Guide to Sailing the Sea of Story by Ursula K. Le Guin

YouTube Channels for Semester 6 Subjects:

    English: Writing Business

    Hindi: Literary Magazines Hindi

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

This semester emphasizes independent writing and research.

    Independent Creative Project: Work on a significant creative writing project.

    Research in Creative Writing: Explore research methodologies relevant to creative writing.

    Publishing Your Work: Focus on the steps involved in publishing, from query letters to agents.

    Workshops with Guest Writers: Participate in workshops led by published authors.

    Final Portfolio Preparation: Compile a portfolio showcasing your best work.

Recommended Reference Books:

    The Art of Writing Fiction by Andrew L. B. Nunn

    The Writing Life by Annie Dillard

YouTube Channels for Semester 7 Subjects:

    English: Independent Writing

    Hindi: Guest Writers Hindi

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester focuses on capstone projects and career preparation.

    Capstone Project: A comprehensive creative project demonstrating skills learned throughout the program.

    Final Portfolio Presentation: Present your compiled portfolio to peers and faculty.

    Career Paths in Writing: Explore various career opportunities in writing and publishing.

    Networking in the Literary World: Strategies for building connections with agents, publishers, and other writers.

    Reflective Practice: Reflect on personal growth and learning throughout the program.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Making a Literary Life: Advice for Writers and Other Dreamers by Carolyn See

    Writing for the 21st Century: A Guide to Writing and Publishing by Janet Burroway

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: Capstone Project

    Hindi: Literary Careers Hindi

Future Career Paths

Studying Creative Writing opens up diverse career opportunities:

    Novelist: Write and publish novels in various genres.

    Screenwriter: Create scripts for film and television.

    Playwright: Write for theater productions.

    Content Writer: Produce content for websites, blogs, and social media.

    Editor: Work in publishing, helping to refine and publish works.

    Creative Writing Teacher: Teach writing in schools or community programs.

Preparation Tips

Here are some tips to excel in Creative Writing:

    Write Regularly: Establish a consistent writing routine to hone your craft.

    Read Widely: Read a variety of genres and styles to expand your understanding of writing.

    Join Writing Groups: Engage with other writers for feedback and support.

    Embrace Revisions: Be open to revising your work; it's a crucial part of the writing process.

    Attend Workshops: Participate in workshops and seminars to learn from experienced writers.

    Back

Media Studies Course

Back

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the foundational concepts of media studies.

    Introduction to Media Studies: Overview of media theory, history, and practice.

    Media Literacy: Critical analysis of media messages and their societal impact.

    Communication Theory: Study of major communication models and theories.

    Visual Communication: Understanding the role of images in media.

    Introduction to Journalism: Basics of news writing and reporting.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Understanding Media: The Extensions of Man by Marshall McLuhan

    The Media and Communications in Australia by Stuart Cunningham and Graeme Turner

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: Media Studies

    Hindi: Journalism Basics Hindi

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

This semester explores media production and critical analysis.

    Media Production: Introduction to basic production techniques across various media.

    Film Studies: Analysis of film as an art form and cultural artifact.

    Radio and Audio Production: Fundamentals of producing radio programs and podcasts.

    Media Ethics: Exploration of ethical issues in media practice.

    Digital Media: Study of the evolution and impact of digital media platforms.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Media Ethics: Key Principles for Responsible Practice by Patrick Lee Plaisance

    Film Art: An Introduction by Barbara K. B. Bordwell and Kristin Thompson

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Film Studies

    Hindi: Audio Production Hindi

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

This semester focuses on media technologies and their societal implications.

    Media Technologies: Exploration of current media technologies and their applications.

    Advertising and Public Relations: Understanding the roles of advertising and PR in media.

    Media and Society: Investigating the relationship between media and cultural practices.

    Documentary Studies: Analysis of documentary films and their social impact.

    New Media Theory: Theoretical frameworks for understanding new media.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Media Society: Industries, Images, and Audiences by C. Richard King

    Advertising: Principles and Practice by William Arens

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: Media Technologies

    Hindi: Advertising Hindi

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

This semester delves into specialized media studies topics.

    Global Media: Understanding media's role in globalization and cultural exchange.

    Media and Identity: Exploring how media constructs and represents identities.

    Interactive Media: Study of interactive media forms such as video games.

    Television Studies: Analysis of television as a cultural and social institution.

    Research Methods in Media Studies: Introduction to qualitative and quantitative research methods.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Global Media: New Approaches to Theory and Practice by John Corner and David Pels

    The Television Studies Reader by Bob McNair and James P. McHugh

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: Global Media

    Hindi: Television Studies Hindi

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

This semester emphasizes advanced topics and practical experience.

    Advanced Media Production: Hands-on experience in producing various media formats.

    Media and Politics: Investigate the influence of media on political processes.

    Social Media and Society: Study the impact of social media on communication and culture.

    Media Criticism: Develop skills in critiquing and analyzing media content.

    Internship in Media: Practical experience in a media-related work environment.

Recommended Reference Books:

    The Media and Politics by John Street

    Social Media: A Critical Introduction by Christian Fuchs

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: Media Politics

    Hindi: Social Media Hindi

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

This semester focuses on the relationship between media and cultural practices.

    Media and Cultural Studies: Examining the intersection of media and culture.

    Representation in Media: Understanding issues of representation and diversity.

    Critical Media Studies: Advanced theoretical frameworks for media analysis.

    Documentary Production: Practical experience in creating documentary films.

    Global Communication: Theories and practices in international communication.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Media Culture: An Introduction by Douglas Kellner

    Cultural Studies: Theory and Practice by Chris Barker

YouTube Channels for Semester 6 Subjects:

    English: Media Culture

    Hindi: Representation Hindi

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

This semester emphasizes independent research and capstone projects.

    Independent Research Project: Conduct research on a media-related topic.

    Media Project Development: Develop and present a comprehensive media project.

    Media Law and Policy: Study laws governing media practice.

    Networking in Media: Strategies for building connections in the media industry.

    Guest Lectures from Industry Professionals: Learn from experts in various media fields.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Media Law: A User's Guide for Film and TV Producers by Alison R. Marshall

    Networking for Nerds by Tara Brown

YouTube Channels for Semester 7 Subjects:

    English: Media Law

    Hindi: Networking Hindi

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester focuses on career preparation and industry engagement.

    Capstone Project: A comprehensive project that showcases skills and knowledge acquired.

    Career Opportunities in Media: Explore various career paths in media and communication.

    Portfolio Development: Compile a professional portfolio of work.

    Industry Trends and Future Directions: Study emerging trends in media and technology.

    Reflective Practice: Reflect on personal growth and learning throughout the program.

Recommended Reference Books:

    The Media's Role in Society: An Introduction to Media Studies by Anne Hollander

    Career Opportunities in Media by Susan M. R. Brody

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: Capstone Project

    Hindi: Media Career Hindi

Future Career Paths

Studying Media Studies opens up diverse career opportunities:

    Journalist: Write and report news for various media outlets.

    Media Producer: Create content for television, film, or online platforms.

    Public Relations Specialist: Manage communication between organizations and the public.

    Social Media Manager: Oversee social media strategy and content for brands.

    Media Analyst: Analyze media trends and audience engagement.

    Academic Researcher: Conduct research in media and communication studies.

Preparation Tips

Here are some tips to excel in Media Studies:

    Stay Informed: Keep up with current events and trends in media.

    Engage with Media: Analyze different media forms critically.

    Network: Attend industry events and build connections with professionals.

    Practice Production Skills: Work on media projects to gain practical experience.

    Develop Critical Thinking: Cultivate a critical approach to media consumption and production.

    Back

International Relations Course

Back

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the foundational concepts of international relations.

    Introduction to International Relations: Overview of key theories and concepts in the field.

    Global Politics: Study of political systems and their interactions on a global scale.

    History of International Relations: Examination of historical events that shaped international relations.

    International Organizations: Understanding the role and impact of organizations like the UN.

    Research Methods in Social Sciences: Introduction to qualitative and quantitative research methods.

Recommended Reference Books:

    International Relations: A Very Short Introduction by Paul Wilkinson

    Understanding International Relations by Chris Brown and Kirsten Ainley

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: International Relations

    Hindi: Global Politics Hindi

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

This semester explores theories and approaches to international relations.

    Theories of International Relations: In-depth study of realism, liberalism, constructivism, etc.

    International Law: Understanding the principles and practices of international law.

    Comparative Politics: Comparative analysis of different political systems.

    Foreign Policy Analysis: Examination of how states formulate and implement foreign policy.

    International Political Economy: Study of the relationship between politics and economics on a global scale.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Theories of International Relations by Scott Burchill et al.

    International Law: A Very Short Introduction by Vaughan Lowe

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: IR Theories

    Hindi: International Law Hindi

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

This semester focuses on specific regions and global issues.

    Regional Studies: In-depth analysis of specific regions (e.g., Asia, Europe, Middle East).

    Global Security Issues: Examination of threats to global security, including terrorism and conflict.

    Human Rights in International Relations: Study of human rights norms and violations globally.

    Environmental Politics: Exploration of global environmental issues and governance.

    International Trade and Economics: Analysis of trade policies and their international impact.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Global Security and International Relations by David J. Whittaker

    Human Rights: A Very Short Introduction by Andrew Clapham

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: Global Security

    Hindi: Human Rights Hindi

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

This semester delves into international relations practice and diplomacy.

    Diplomacy: Understanding diplomatic practices and negotiations.

    Conflict Resolution and Peacebuilding: Study of strategies for resolving conflicts and building peace.

    International Development: Examination of global development policies and practices.

    Media and International Relations: Exploring the role of media in shaping international perceptions.

    Intelligence and National Security: Overview of intelligence operations and national security issues.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Diplomacy: Theory and Practice by G.R. Berridge

    International Development: Ideas, Experience, and Prospects by John Toye and Richard Toye

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: Diplomacy

    Hindi: Conflict Resolution Hindi

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

This semester emphasizes advanced topics in international relations.

    Advanced Foreign Policy Analysis: In-depth examination of foreign policy decision-making processes.

    Global Governance: Study of the structures and processes of global governance.

    International Political Economy: Analysis of the interplay between politics and economics globally.

    International Relations and Gender: Exploring the gender dimensions of international relations.

    Internship in International Relations: Practical experience in a relevant organization or agency.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Global Governance: A Very Short Introduction by Jan Aart Scholte

    Gender in International Relations: Feminist Perspectives on Achieving Global Security by J. Ann Tickner

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: Global Governance

    Hindi: Gender Relations Hindi

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

This semester focuses on regional and global case studies.

    Case Studies in International Relations: Analysis of significant international events and decisions.

    Regional Security Studies: Focus on security dynamics in specific regions.

    International Relations and Technology: Examining the impact of technology on international relations.

    Public Diplomacy: Understanding the role of public diplomacy in international relations.

    Research Project in International Relations: Conducting an independent research project.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Case Studies in International Relations by Robert J. Jackson

    Public Diplomacy: Ideas for the War of Ideas by Philip M. Taylor

YouTube Channels for Semester 6 Subjects:

    English: Case Studies IR

    Hindi: Public Diplomacy Hindi

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

This semester focuses on specialized topics and practical skills.

    International Humanitarian Law: Study of laws governing armed conflict and humanitarian aid.

    Global Health and Security: Examining the intersection of global health and international security.

    International Relations and the Environment: Understanding environmental challenges in international relations.

    Skills for International Relations Practitioners: Developing key skills for a career in international relations.

    Internship Report: Reflection and analysis of internship experience.

Recommended Reference Books:

    International Humanitarian Law by Theodor Meron

    Global Health Security: A Critical Global Health Priority by Richard Coker et al.

YouTube Channels for Semester 7 Subjects:

    English: International Humanitarian Law

    Hindi: Global Health Hindi

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester emphasizes career preparation and integration of knowledge.

    Capstone Project: A comprehensive project showcasing skills and knowledge acquired throughout the course.

    Career Opportunities in International Relations: Exploration of various career paths in the field.

    Portfolio Development: Compiling a professional portfolio of work.

    Ethics in International Relations: Study of ethical considerations in international decision-making.

    Reflective Practice: Reflecting on personal growth and learning throughout the program.

Recommended Reference Books:

    International Ethics: A Critical Introduction by Thomas S. Bianchi

    Career Opportunities in International Relations by Susan M. R. Brody

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: Capstone in International Relations

    Hindi: International Relations Career Hindi

Future Career Paths

Studying International Relations opens up diverse career opportunities:

    Diplomat: Representing a country in foreign affairs.

    International Development Officer: Working with NGOs or government agencies on development projects.

    Foreign Affairs Analyst: Analyzing international events and their implications.

    Policy Advisor: Advising on foreign policy decisions.

    Academic Researcher: Conducting research in international relations and political science.

    Consultant: Providing expertise on international business and relations.

Preparation Tips

Here are some tips to excel in International Relations:

    Stay Informed: Keep up with current events and trends in international relations.

    Engage in Discussions: Participate in debates and discussions on global issues.

    Network: Attend conferences and seminars to connect with professionals.

    Develop Critical Thinking: Analyze different perspectives on international issues critically.

    Practice Research Skills: Conduct independent research to deepen your understanding.

    Back

Political Science Course

Back

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces foundational concepts in political science.

    Introduction to Political Science: Overview of political systems, ideologies, and institutions.

    Political Theory: Introduction to key political theories and thinkers.

    Comparative Politics: Examining different political systems and their comparisons.

    Indian Politics: Understanding the political system and dynamics in India.

    Research Methods in Political Science: Introduction to qualitative and quantitative research methodologies.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Political Science: A Very Short Introduction by Andrew Heywood

    Comparative Politics: A Global Introduction by Michael G. Roskin et al.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

    English: Political Science

    Hindi: Indian Politics Hindi

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

This semester explores deeper theoretical and practical aspects of political science.

    Political Ideologies: Study of major ideologies including liberalism, conservatism, socialism, etc.

    International Relations: Introduction to global politics and international relations theories.

    Public Administration: Understanding the structure and functions of government administration.

    Political Parties and Elections: Analysis of party systems and electoral processes.

    Constitutional Law: Overview of constitutional principles and legal frameworks.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Political Ideologies: An Introduction by Andrew Heywood

    Public Administration: A Very Short Introduction by Mark Bevir

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

    English: Political Ideologies

    Hindi: Public Administration Hindi

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

This semester focuses on advanced political theories and practices.

    Comparative Government: In-depth analysis of different governmental systems worldwide.

    Political Sociology: Examination of the relationship between society and politics.

    Public Policy: Understanding the process of policy-making and its implications.

    Human Rights and Political Justice: Study of human rights principles in political contexts.

    Political Economy: Exploration of the interplay between politics and economics.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Comparative Government and Politics by G. H. McLean and A. H. McMillan

    Human Rights: A Very Short Introduction by Andrew Clapham

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

    English: Comparative Government

    Hindi: Human Rights Hindi

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

This semester delves into political processes and institutions.

    Political Methodology: Understanding research methods and data analysis in political science.

    Government and Politics in India: Detailed study of the Indian political system.

    International Political Economy: Analysis of the global political economy and its dynamics.

    Media and Politics: Examining the role of media in shaping political discourse.

    Ethics in Politics: Exploration of ethical issues in political practices.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Research Design: Qualitative, Quantitative, and Mixed Methods Approaches by Charles R. Schreiber

    Media, Politics, and Policy in a Changing World by David C. Horton

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

    English: Political Methodology

    Hindi: Media Politics Hindi

Semester 5

Semester 5 Subjects:

This semester emphasizes specialized topics and contemporary issues in politics.

    Global Politics: Analysis of political interactions at the international level.

    Political Psychology: Understanding the psychological factors influencing political behavior.

    Comparative Public Policy: Examination of public policies across different countries.

    Conflict and Cooperation in International Relations: Study of international conflicts and resolutions.

    Research Project in Political Science: Conducting an independent research project on a relevant topic.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Global Politics: A New Introduction by Jenny Edkins and Nick Vaughan-Williams

    Political Psychology: An Introduction by Barbara A. Bardes and Jennifer A. K. L. Bodine

YouTube Channels for Semester 5 Subjects:

    English: Global Politics

    Hindi: Political Psychology Hindi

Semester 6

Semester 6 Subjects:

This semester focuses on advanced topics and case studies in political science.

    Case Studies in Political Science: Analysis of significant political events and decisions.

    Politics of Development: Examining the relationship between politics and development.

    Environmental Politics: Study of environmental issues and their political implications.

    Political Economy of Globalization: Understanding the impacts of globalization on politics and economy.

    Internship in Political Science: Practical experience in a political or governmental setting.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Development as Freedom by Amartya Sen

    Globalization: A Very Short Introduction by Manfred B. Steger

YouTube Channels for Semester 6 Subjects:

    English: Case Studies in Political Science

    Hindi: Political Economy Hindi

Semester 7

Semester 7 Subjects:

This semester emphasizes specialized topics and practical skills.

    International Law: Study of laws governing relations between states.

    Political Theory of Globalization: Understanding the political implications of globalization.

    Women and Politics: Examining the role of gender in politics.

    Political Communication: Analyzing the communication strategies used in politics.

    Internship Report: Reflection and analysis of internship experience.

Recommended Reference Books:

    International Law by Malcolm N. Shaw

    Gender and Politics: A Comparative Perspective by Jill M. Hargreaves

YouTube Channels for Semester 7 Subjects:

    English: International Law

    Hindi: Women in Politics Hindi

Semester 8

Semester 8 Subjects:

The final semester emphasizes career preparation and integration of knowledge.

    Capstone Project: A comprehensive project showcasing skills and knowledge acquired throughout the course.

    Career Opportunities in Political Science: Exploration of various career paths in the field.

    Portfolio Development: Compiling a professional portfolio of work.

    Ethics in Political Science: Study of ethical considerations in political decision-making.

    Reflective Practice: Reflecting on personal growth and learning throughout the program.

Recommended Reference Books:

    Ethics in Politics: A Practical Guide by Michael J. Shapiro

    Career Opportunities in Political Science by Robert D. Hare

YouTube Channels for Semester 8 Subjects:

    English: Capstone in Political Science

    Hindi: Political Science Career Hindi

Future Career Paths

Studying Political Science opens up diverse career opportunities:

    Political Analyst: Analyzing political trends and advising on policy decisions.

    Public Policy Consultant: Providing expertise in public policy formulation.

    Government Officer: Working in various governmental roles and functions.

    Diplomat: Representing a country in international affairs.

    Academic Researcher: Conducting research in political science and academia.

    Journalist: Reporting on political issues and events.

Preparation Tips

Here are some tips to excel in Political Science:

    Stay Informed: Keep up with current events and trends in politics.

    Engage in Discussions: Participate in debates and discussions on political issues.

    Network: Attend political events and seminars to connect with professionals.

    Develop Critical Thinking: Analyze different perspectives on political matters critically.

    Practice Research Skills: Conduct independent research to deepen your understanding.
